{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2014 UR|116}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2014 UR|116}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =  <ref name="jpldata" /><ref name="MPC-2014UR116" /> | discovered = 1 December 2008 | discoverer = [[Mount Lemmon Survey|Mount Lemmon Srvy.]] | discovery_site = [[Mount Lemmon Observatory|Mount Lemmon Obs.]] | mpc_name = {{mp|2014 UR|116}} | alt_names = {{mp|2014 UR|116}}{{·}}{{mp|2008 XB}} | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]{{·}}[[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]] <ref name="jpldata" /><ref name="MPC-2014UR116" /> | orbit_ref =  <ref name="jpldata" /> | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 8.23 yr (3,005 days) | aphelion = 3.5757 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.5648 AU | semimajor = 2.0703 AU | eccentricity = 0.7272 | period = 2.98 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1,088 days) | mean_anomaly = 2.0212[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.3309|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 6.5740° | asc_node = 6.0028° | arg_peri = 286.79° | moid = 0.0290 AU{{·}}11.3 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | dimensions = 0.4 km<ref name="JPL-statement" /> | rotation = | albedo = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 19.7<ref name="jpldata" /> }}
'''{{mp|2014 UR|116}}''', also known as '''2008 XB''', is an eccentric sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], categorized as a [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]] with a diameter of approximately {{convert|400|m|ft|sp=us}}.<ref name="JPL-statement" /> It was first observed on 1 December 2008, by the [[Mount Lemmon Survey]] at [[Mount Lemmon Observatory]] in Arizona, United States.<ref name="MPC-2014UR116" />
== Orbit ==
{{mp|2014 UR|116}} orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.6–3.6 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 3 years (1,088 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.73 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 7[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]].<ref name="jpldata" />
=== Close approaches ===
The asteroid has an Earth [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] of {{convert |0.0290 |AU |km |abbr=on |sigfig=3}} which translates into 11.3 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]].<ref name="jpldata" /> On 21 October 2014, it passed {{convert |0.0854 |AU |km mi |abbr=on}} from Earth.<ref name=jpl-close /> On 10 April 2047, the asteroid will safely pass {{convert |0.0296 |AU |km mi |abbr=on |lk=off}} from Earth.<ref name=jpl-close />
Although some inaccurate press reports have suggested that it may pose an impact risk to Earth, the NASA/JPL Near Earth Object Program Office reported that it poses no risk of impact to any planet for at least 150 years.<ref name="JPL-statement"/><ref name=nbc>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/nasa-says-asteroid-2014-ur116-nothing-be-afraid-n264281|title=NASA Says Asteroid 2014 UR116 Is Nothing to Be Afraid Of |date=9 December 2014|publisher=[[NBC News]]}}</ref> Between 1904 and 2174, the closest approach it makes to any planet was on 9 June 2008 when it passed {{convert |0.0144 |AU|km mi |abbr=on}} from Mars. The asteroid has never been listed on the [[Sentry Risk Table]] and has a well determined orbit with an [[observation arc]] of 6 years.<ref name=jpl-close />
== Discovery ==
The asteroid was first detected on 1 December 2008 by the [[Mount Lemmon Survey]] and received the [[Provisional designation in astronomy|provisional designation]] {{mp|2008 XB}}.<ref name="MPC-2014UR116" /> However, at an [[apparent magnitude]] of 20 and an assumed [[orbital eccentricity]] of 0.3, the object had a very short observation arc of less than 2 hours and the body became a [[lost minor planet]].<ref name="MPEC2008-X16" /> It was only recovered as {{mp|2014 UR|116}} on 27 October 2014, by observers at the MASTER-II Observatory ({{small|[[IAU code#C41|C41]]}}) at [[Pulkovo Observatory]] in Kislovodsk, Russia.<ref name=jpl-close />
== See also == * {{mpl|2014 OO|6}}, one of the most dangerous asteroids discovered in 2014 that is on the Sentry Risk Table
== References == {{reflist|30em|refs=
<ref name="jpldata">{{cite web |type = 2017-02-22 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2014 UR116) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3440794 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 2 August 2017}}</ref>
<ref name="MPC-2014UR116">{{cite web |title = 2014 UR116 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2014+UR116 |accessdate = 2 August 2017}}</ref>
<ref name="JPL-statement">{{cite web |title = Asteroid 2014 UR116, A 400-meter Sized Near-Earth Asteroid, Represents No Threat to the Earth |last = Yeomans |first=Don |last2 = Baalke |first2=Ron |date = 8 December 2014 |publisher = NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url = http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news187.html |deadurl = yes |archivedate= 9 February 2015 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150209020721/http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news187.html}}</ref>
<ref name=jpl-close>{{cite web |type=last observation: 11 December 2014; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 6 years |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: (2014 UR116) |url=https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2014UR116;cad=1#cad |accessdate=10 December 2014}}</ref>
<ref name="MPEC2008-X16">{{cite web |title=MPEC 2008-X16 : 2008 XB |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=1 December 2008 |url=https://www.minorplanetcenter.org/mpec/K08/K08X16.html |accessdate=10 December 2014}} (K08X00B)</ref>
}} <!-- end of reflist -->
== External links == * {{JPL small body|id=3440794}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2013}} '''ALINDIEN''' is a [[French Navy|French naval]] acronym designing the admiral in charge of the maritime zone of the [[Indian Ocean]], and of the French forces there. The office has been held by [[Contre-amiral]] Didier Piaton since 8 September 2016.
== Organisation ==
=== Zone of authority === [[Image:Océan Indien.png|thumb|Indian Ocean]] ALINDIEN's jurisdiction extends over the maritime zone of the [[Indian Ocean]], dubbed "ZMOI" (''zone maritime de l'océan Indien''): it comprises the area bounded on its Western part by the Red Sea and Africa, and on its Eastern part by Philippines and Viet Nam. The zone notably comprises such strategic areas as the Persian Gulf, Southern Africa, India, Australia and Singapore.
The zones of [[La Réunion]] and of the [[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]] operate under a different hierarchy.
=== Missions === In his role as a maritime zone commander, ALINDIEN operates directly under the [[Chief of the Defence Staff (France)|Chief of the Defence Staff]]. As a fleet commander, he operates under [[ALFAN]], the Admiral in charge of the ''[[Force d'action navale]]'' for matters of management, training and preparation of the units permanently stationed in the Indian Ocean. The units are mostly stationed in [[La Réunion]] and [[Djibouti]].
ALINDIEN is tasked with the operational control of the naval forces deployed in his area, unless they are detached with their own general staff. This command is exercised from a [[Durance-class tanker|''Durance'' class]] command and replenishment oiler (BCR) carrying the entire general staff. Which exact ship is deployed depends on unit turnover, as the ships are relieved every four years; the [[French ship Marne (A630)|''Marne'' (A630)]] has served in this capacity from the summer of 2002.<ref name="alindien">[http://www.netmarine.net/bat/pr/marne/alindien.htm L'amiral commandant la Zone Maritime Océan Indien], netmarine.net</ref> ALINDIEN was the only naval command of the French Navy that is permanently stationed at sea. In autumn 2010, the commanding staff moved ashore to the [[Abu Dhabi base]] and the permanently sea-stationed status of the command ended.<ref>http://www.meretmarine.com/article.cfm?id=113659, 09/07/2010</ref>
ALINDIEN also has duties in defence diplomacy with all neighbouring countries.
He supervises the French bases in [[Djibouti]], [[La Réunion]], and the [[Abu Dhabi base]] (since 2009).
=== Deployment === The following units are permanently under ALINDIEN command: * [[French frigate Nivôse (F732)|''Nivôse'' (F732)]], [[Floréal class frigate|''Floréal'' class frigate]] based in [[La Réunion]] * [[French frigate Floréal (F730)|''Floréal'' (F730)]], [[Floréal class frigate|''Floréal'' class frigate]] based in [[La Réunion]] * Commando ''Arta'', a 60-man commando based in [[Djibouti]] * One [[Atlantique 2]] naval patrol plane, based in Djibouti
Reinforcements can be deployed under ALINDIEN's authority for punctual operations.
== History == During the [[Iran-Iraq war]], ALINDIEN's office managed the ''Opération Promethée'', that aimed at preventing any action from either Iraq or Iran against oil shipping. Minesweepers were deployed in several occasions to secure shipping lines.
In January 1986, Vice-amiral Gilbert Le Meledo carried out evacuation of the foreign citizens from [[Aden]]. The ''[[French ship Jules Verne (A620)|Jules Verne]]'' was particularly involved in the operation.<ref>[http://www.netmarine.net/bat/bsm/jverne/histoire02.htm L'histoire du BAP ''Jules Verne''], netmarine</ref>
During the [[Gulf War]], Contre-amiral Pierre Bonnot commanded a number of war actions, and was later involved in enforcing the [[Iraq sanctions]], as well as minesweeping in Koweiti waters.
In 1992, Contre-amiral Gérard Gazzano and Hubert Foillard supported the [[United Nations Operation in Somalia I]]. From March 1993 until March 1995, Admirals Hubert Foillard and Jean-Luc Delaunay supported [[UNOSOM II]]. From 8 to 14 April 1994, Delaunay also supervised a second evacuation of foreign citizens from [[Aden]], with ''Jules Verne'' playing a prominent role again.
In 1996, Contre-amiral Alain Béreau supervised [[Operation Condor (1996)|Operation Condor]], a UN mission to monitor [[Hanish Islands]] in the context of a mediation between Yemen and Erythrea.
In 1998, Contre-amiral Jean-Louis Battet supervised [[Operation Khor Angar]], securing the shores of Djibouti during the [[Eritrean–Ethiopian War]].
From 2001, [[Opération Héracles]] has been in force,{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} in the context of the "[[War on Terror]]".
In January 2005, Vice-amiral Xavier Rolin supervised [[Opération Beryx]], a humanitarian mission to relieve populations victim of the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]]. The ''[[French frigate Dupleix (D641)|Dupleix]]'', ''[[French frigate Georges Leygues (D640)|Georges Leygues]]'' and ''[[French cruiser Jeanne d'Arc (R97)|Jeanne d'Arc]]'' were notably involved.
== Notes == <references /> *See also 'Interview,' Helmoed-Romer Heitman with Rear Admiral Alain Bereau (Alindien), Jane's Defence Weekly 4 December 1996, p. 40
==External links== * [http://www.netmarine.net/bat/pr/marne/zmoi.htm Zone maritime de l'océan Indien], netmarine.net * [http://www.netmarine.net/bat/pr/marne/alindien.htm Alindien], netmarine.net * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080513163116/http://www.editions-sudouest.com/1010-Alindien-telegra.html '''Alindien'''], vice-Admiral [[Laurent Mérer]], Ed. Le Télégramme, {{ISBN|2-84833-167-4}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Alindien}} [[Category:Indian Ocean]] [[Category:French Navy admirals]] [[Category:French naval components]]

In [[Greek mythology]], '''Agave''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|ɡ|ə|v|i}}; [[Ancient Greek]]: Ἀγαύη, ''Agauē'', "illustrious") may refer to the following characters:
* Agave, one of the [[Nereids]].<ref>[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+1.2.7 1.2.7]; [[Homer]], ''[[Iliad]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text;jsessionid=DBECE22540D7116390AD12F52D9ADC80?doc=Hom.+Il.+18.35 18.35]; [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+240 240]; [[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'' [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HyginusFabulae1.html Preface].</ref> *Agave, one of the [[Danaids]], daughter of [[Danaus]], king of [[Libya]] and [[Europa (Greek myth)|Europa]], a queen. She married [[Lycus (mythology)|Lycus]], son of [[Aegyptus]] and [[Argyphia]].<ref>[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+2.1.5 2.1.5].</ref> *[[Agave (Theban princess)|Agave]], daughter of [[Cadmus]].<ref name=":0">[[Apollodorus of Athens|Pseudo-Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]] [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+3.4.2 3.4.2].''</ref> *Agave, an [[Amazons|Amazon]].<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'' [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HyginusFabulae4.html#163 163].</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}{{Greek myth index}} [[Category:Danaids]] [[Category:Nereids]] [[Category:Amazons (Greek mythology)]] [[Category:Women in Greek mythology]]

{{taxobox | name = Anigre | image = | image_alt = | image_caption = | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] | unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] | unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] | ordo = [[Ericales]] | familia = [[Sapotaceae]] | subfamilia = [[Chrysophylloideae]] | genus = [[Pouteria]] (and [[Chrysophyllum]]) | species = {{species list |[[Pouteria altissima|P. altissima]]|(A.Chev.) Baehni |[[Aningueria robusta|P. pierrei]]|(A.Chev.) Baehni |P. superba|(Vermoesen) L.Gaut. |C. giganteum|A.Chev. }} | binomial = | binomial_authority = }}
'''Anigre''' is an African [[hardwood]] commonly used for [[plywood]], interior furniture, cabinetry, and high-end [[Millwork (building material)|millwork]] applications. It is frequently sliced and sold as [[Wood veneer|veneer]], although it is available in board form as well. In board form it is used for boat building, general carpentry, and other light construction uses.
==Characteristics== It is considered a tropical hardwood with a clear, cylindrical bole to {{convert|80|ft}}. It can grow to heights of {{convert|180|ft}} with typical trunk diameters ranging from {{convert|36|to|48|in}}. Anigre has a medium texture with closed pores similar to maple. Growth rings aren’t always well-defined, and the wood can be rather plain-looking; though certain figure is occasionally present, such as curly or mottled grain. The [[sapwood (wood)|sapwood]] and the [[heartwood]] are not usually distinguishable. The heartwood is a light yellowish-brown, sometimes with a pinkish hue. Color tends to darken with age. The quarter figured veneer has become a popular choice for furniture, cabinetry, and decorative architectural applications. It is said to have a faint odor similar to Cedar. In its untreated form Anigre is susceptible to termite and fungi attacks and generally has low durability. Anigre is usually considered easy to work with hand and power tools, although depending on the origin of the wood it can have a high [[silica]] content which can dull wood working tools quickly.[[File:Anigre.jpg|thumb|Quarter Figured Anigre]] [[File:Aningeria sp MHNT.BOT.2010.6.80.jpg|thumb|''Aningeria sp'' - [[MHNT]]]]
==Origins== Anigre is often found in tropical East and West Africa, primarily in [[Cameroon]] but also in Angola, Congo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guinea Bissau, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Uganda and Zaire.<ref>Wood River Veneer http://wood-veneer.com/product.php?veneer=Anigre%20Veneer</ref> Exportation from Cameroon is actually prohibited by local laws.
==Common Names== Anigre, Anegre, Aniegre, Aningré, [[Aningeria]], Aninguerie, Mugangu, Muna, Osan, Anegre Blanc, Longhi, Mukaly, Tanganyika Nuss. Common pronunciations vary from Ah-Nee-Grey, Ah-Nee-Gra, Anna-Gra, Anna-Grey, Uh-Nee-Grey.
==Scientific Names== Genus: [[Pouteria]] <ref>Tropix {{cite web|url=http://tropix.cirad.fr/africa/ANINGRE.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509195507/http://tropix.cirad.fr/africa/ANINGRE.pdf |archivedate=2012-05-09 |df= }}</ref> Family: [[Sapotaceae]] (Angiosperm). [[Pouteria altissima|Aningeria Altissima]],<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-163903 The Plant List: Pouteria altissima]</ref> Aningeria Robusta,<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-164349 The Plant List: Pouteria pierrei]</ref> Aningeria Superba,<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-164482 The Plant List: Pouteria superba]</ref> [[Chrysophyllum|Gambeyobotrys]] Gigantea<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-40081 The Plant List: Chrysophyllum giganteum]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Wood]]

revision.text:
{{short description|Late-Proterozoic to early-Palaeozoic continent}} {{about|a continent}} [[File:Baltica outline.png|thumb|Outline of Baltica]] '''Baltica''' is a [[paleocontinent]] that formed in the [[Paleoproterozoic]] and now constitutes northwestern [[Eurasia]], or Europe north of the [[Trans-European Suture Zone]] and west of the [[Ural Mountains]]. The thick core of Baltica, the [[East European Craton]], is more than three billion years old and formed part of the [[Rodinia]] supercontinent at {{Circa}} 1 {{Abbr|Ga|Billion years ago}}.<ref>{{Harvnb|Cocks|Torsvik|2005|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
==Tectonic history== [[File:Baltica 1100 Ma.png|thumb|1.1 Ga Baltica was located in what is now the South Pacific. (Current location of Australia added for reference.)]] [[Image:Positions_of_ancient_continents,_550_million_years_ago.jpg|thumb|550 million years ago Baltica (green) was an isolated continent located near the South Pole.]] Baltica formed at {{Circa}} 2.0–1.7 Ga by the collision of three [[Archean|Archaean]]-[[Proterozoic]] continental blocks: [[Fennoscandia]] (including the exposed [[Baltic Shield]]), [[Sarmatian Craton|Sarmatia]] ([[Ukrainian Shield]] and [[Voronezh Massif]]), and [[Volgo-Uralia]] (covered by younger deposits). Sarmatia and Volgo-Uralia formed a proto-[[craton]] (sometimes called "Proto-Baltica")<ref>E.g. {{Harvnb|Torsvik|Cocks|2005|loc=Norway’s earliest times, pp. 74–75}}</ref> at c. 2.0 Ga which collided with Fennoscandia c. 1.8–1.7 Ga. The [[Suture (geology)|suture]]s between these three blocks were reactivated during the Mesoproterozoic and Neoproterozoic.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bogdanova|Bingen|Gorbatschev|Kheraskova|2008|loc=The crustal segments of the East European Craton, pp. 2–3}}</ref>
750–600 million years ago, Baltica and [[Laurentia]] rotated clockwise together and drifted away from the Equator towards the South Pole where they were affected by the [[Cryogenian]] [[Varanger glaciation]]s. Initial rifting between the two continents is marked by the c. 650 Ma [[Egersund dike swarm]] in southern Norway and from 600 Ma they began to rotate up to 180° relative to each other, thus opening the [[Iapetus Ocean]] between them. Laurentia quickly moved northward but Baltica remained an isolated continent in the Southern Hemisphere closer to [[Gondwana]] on which endemic [[trilobite]]s evolved in the Early Ordovician.<ref name="Tors-1996-Abst">{{Harvnb|Torsvik|Smethurst|Meert|Van der Voo|1996|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
During the Ordovician, Baltica moved northward approaching Laurentia again allowing trilobites and brachiopods to cross the Iapetus Ocean. In the Silurian, c. 425 Ma, the final collision between Scotland-Greenland and Norway resulted in the [[Caledonian orogeny#Scandian/Grampian phase|Scandian Orogeny]].<ref name="Tors-1996-Abst" />
==Margins== Baltica is a very old continent and its core is a very well-preserved and thick craton. Its current margins, however, are the [[Suture (geology)|sutures]] that are the result of mergers with other, much younger continental blocks. These often deformed sutures do not represent the original, Precambrian–early Palaeozoic extent of Baltica; for example, the curved margin north of the Urals running parallel to Novaya Zemlya was probably deformed during the eruption of the End-Permian [[Siberian Traps]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Cocks|Torsvik|2005|loc=The margins of Baltica, p. 41}}</ref>
Baltica's western margin is the [[Caledonian orogeny|Caledonide orogen]] which stretches northward from the [[Scandinavian Mountains]] across [[Barents Sea]] to [[Svalbard]]. Its eastern margin is the [[Timanide Orogen|Timanide orogen]] which stretches north to the [[Novaya Zemlya]] archipelago.<ref>{{Harvnb|Gee|Bogolepova|Lorenz|2006|p=507}}</ref> The extent of the Proterozoic continent are defined by the [[Iapetus Suture]] to the west; the [[Trollfjorden-Komagelva Fault Zone]] in the north; the [[Variscan orogeny|Variscan-Hercynian]] suture to the south; the [[Tornquist Zone]] to the southwest; and the [[Ural Mountains]] to the east.<ref>{{Harvnb|Torsvik|Smethurst|Van der Voo|Trench|1992|loc=Introduction, pp. 133–137}}</ref>
===Northern margin=== At c. 555 Ma during the [[Timanide Orogen|Timanian Orogeny]] the northern margin became an active margin and Baltica expanded northward with the accretion of a series of continental blocks: the [[Timan-Pechora Basin]], the northern-most Ural Mountains, and the [[Novaya Zemlya]] islands. This expansion coincided with the [[Varanger glaciation]]s, also known as [[Snowball Earth]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Walderhaug|Torsvik|Halvorsen|2007|loc=Baltica and Varangian Glaciations, pp. 946–947; Fig. 12, p. 946}}</ref>
[[Terrane]]s of the [[North American Cordillera]], including [[Arctic Alaska-Chukotka terrane|Alaska-Chukotka]], [[Alexander terrane|Alexander]], [[Northern Sierra terrane|Northern Sierra]], and [[eastern Klamath terrane|Eastern Klamath]], share a rift history with Baltica and most likely were part of Baltica from the Caledonian orogeny to the formation of the Ural Mountains.<ref>{{Harvnb|Miller|Kuznetsov|Soboleva|Udoratina|2011|loc=Abstract}}</ref> These terranes can be linked to either northeastern Laurentia, Baltica, or Siberia because of a similar sequence of fossils; [[Detritus (geology)|detrital]] zircon from 2-1 Ga-old sources and evidence of Grenvillian magmatism; and magmatism and [[island arc]]s from the Late Neoproterozoic and Ordovician-Silurian.<ref>{{Harvnb|Colpron|Nelson|2009|loc=Terranes of Siberian, Baltican and Caledonian affinities, pp. 280–281}}</ref>
===Southern margin=== From at least 1.8 Ga to at least 0.8 Ga the southwestern margin of Baltica was connected to [[Amazonian Craton|Amazonia]] while the southeast margin was connected to the [[West African Craton]]. Baltica, Amazonia, and West Africa rotated 75° clockwise relative to Laurentia until Baltica and Amazonia collided with Laurentia in the 1.1-0.9 Ga [[Grenville orogeny|Grenville]]-[[Sveconorwegian orogeny|Sveconorwegian]]-[[Sunsás orogeny|Sunsás]] orogenies to form the supercontinent [[Rodinia]]. When the break-up of Rodinia was complete c. 0.6 Ga Baltica became an isolated continent — a 200 million year period when Baltica was truly a separate continent.<ref>{{Harvnb|Johansson|2009|loc=Abstract}}</ref> Laurentia and Baltica formed a single continent until 1.265 Ga which broke up some time before 0.99 Ga. After the subsequent closure of the [[Mirovia|Mirovoi Ocean]] Laurentia, Baltica and Amazonia remained merged until the opening of the Iapetus Ocean in the Neoproterozoic.<ref>{{Harvnb|Cawood|Pisarevsky|2017|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
===Western Margin=== The [[Western Gneiss Region]] in northern Norway is composed of 1650-950 Ma-old gneisses overlain by [[Continental crust|continental]] and [[Oceanic crust|oceanic]] [[allochton]]s that were transferred from Laurentia to Baltica during the Scandian orogeny. The allochtons were accreted to Baltica during the closure of the Iapetus Ocean c. 430-410 Ma; Baltica's [[Basement (geology)|basement]] and the allochtons were then subducted to [[Ultra-high-pressure metamorphism|UHP]] depth c. 425-400 Ma; and they were finnaly exhumed to their present location c. 400-385 Ma.<ref>{{Harvnb|Hacker|Andersen|Johnston|Kylander-Clark|2010|loc=Western Gneiss Region, pp. 150–151}}</ref> The presence of micro-diamonds in two islands in northern Norway, [[Otrøya]] and [[Flemsøya]], indicate that this margin of Baltica was buried c. {{Convert|120|km|abbr=on}} for at least 25 million years around 429 Ma shortly after the Baltica-Laurentia collision.<ref>{{Harvnb|Spengler|Brueckner|van Roermund|Drury|2009|loc=Abstract; Conclusion and implications, pp. 33–34}}</ref>
The Baltica-Laurentia-Avalonia triple junction in the North Sea is the southwest corner of Baltica. The Baltica-Laurentia suture stretching northeast from the triple junction was deformed in the Late Cambrian and early Palaeozoic in the Scandinavian Caledonides as well as the Scandian Orogeny in the Silurian. Some Norwegian terranes have faunas distinct from those of either Baltica or Laurentia and were island arcs that originated in the Iapetus Ocean and were accreted to Baltica. The Baltica craton most likely underlies these terranes and the [[continent-ocean boundary]] passes several kilometres off Norway, but, since the North Atlantic opened c. 54 Ma were the Iapetus Ocean closed, it is unlikely the craton also reached into Laurentia. The margin stretches north to [[Novaya Zemlya]] where early Palaeozoic Baltica faunas have been found, but the sparsity of data makes it difficult to locate the margin in the Arctic. Ordovician faunas indicate that most of [[Svalbard]], including [[Bear Island (Norway)|Bjørnøya]], was part of Laurentia, but [[Franz Josef Land]] and [[Kvitøya]] (an eastern island of the Svalbard archipelago) most likely became part of Baltica in the Timanide Orogeny. The [[Taymyr Peninsula]], in contrast, never was part of Baltica: southern Taymyr was part of Siberia whilst northern Taymyr and the [[Severnaya Zemlya]] archipelago were part of the independent Kara Terrane in the early Palaeozoic.<ref>{{Harvnb|Cocks|Torsvik|2005|loc=The margins of Baltica, p. 42–44}}</ref>
===Eastern margin=== The eastern margin, the Uralide orogen, extends {{Convert|2500|km|abbr=on}} from the Arctic [[Novaya Zemlya]] archipelago to the [[Aral Sea]]. The orogen contains the record of at least two collisions between Baltica and intra-oceanic island arcs before the final collision between Baltica and [[Kazakhstania]]-[[Siberia (continent)|Siberia]] during the formation of [[Pangaea]]. The Silurian-Devonian island arcs were accreted to Baltica along the [[Main Uralian Fault]], east of which are metamorphosed fragments of volcanic arc mixed with small amounts of Precambrian and Paleozoic continental rocks. No Rocks, however, unambiguously originating from either Kazakhstania or Siberia have been found in the Urals.<ref>{{Harvnb|Brown|Spadea|Puchkov|Alvarez-Marron|2006|loc=Geological framework of the Uralides, p. 262}}; For a model of the arc-continent collsion see {{Harvnb|Puchkov|2009|loc=Fig. 12, p. 178; Fig. 14, p. 180}}</ref> The basement of the eastern margin is composed of an Archaean craton, metamorphosed rocks at least 1.6 Ga-old, which is surrounded by the fold belt of the Timanide orogeny and overlain by Mesoproterozoic sediments. The margin became a [[passive margin]] facing an Ural Ocean in the Cambrian-Ordovician.<ref>{{Harvnb|Brown|Spadea|Puchkov|Alvarez-Marron|2006|loc=The Paleozoic continental margin of Baltica in the Southern Urals, pp. 262–266}}</ref>
The eastern margin stretches south through the Ural Mountains from the northern end of the Novaya Zemlya archipelago. The margin follows the bent shape of Novaya Zemlya which was caused in the Late Permian by the [[Siberian Traps]]. It is clear from Baltic endemic fossils in Novaya Zemlya that the islands have been part of Baltica since Early Palaeozoic, whereas the Taymyr Peninsula farther east was part of the passive margin of Siberia in the Early Palaeozoic. Northern Taymyr, together with Severnaya Zemlya and parts of the crust of the Arctic Ocean formed the [[Kara Terrane]].<ref name="CoTo-2005-p44">{{Harvnb|Cocks|Torsvik|2005|loc=The margins of Baltica, p. 44–45}}</ref>
The Urals Mountains formed in the mid and late Palaeozoic when [[Laurussia]] collided with [[Kazakhstania]], a series of terranes. The eastern margin, however, originally extended farther east to an active margin bordered by [[island arc]]s, but those parts have been compressed, fractured, and distorted especially in the eastern Urals. The early Palaeozoic eastern margin is better preserved south of the polar region (65°N) where shallow-water sediments can be found in the western Urals whilst the eastern Urals are characterised by deep-water deposits. The oldest known [[mid-ocean ridge|mid-ocean]] [[hydrothermal vent]] in the south-central part of the Urals clearly delimits the eastern extent. The straightness of the mountain chain is the result of continuous strike-slip movements during the Late Carboniferous to Early Permian (300-290 Ma).<ref name="CoTo-2005-p44" />
Baltic endemic faunas from the Early Ordovician have been found in Kazakhstan near the southern end of the eastern margin, or the triple junction between Baltica, the [[Mangyshlak Peninsula|Mangyshlak Terrane]], and the accretionary [[Central Asian Orogenic Belt|Altaids]]. Here the early Palaeozoic rocks are buried under the [[Caspian Depression]].<ref name="CoTo-2005-p44" />

__NOTOC__ {{Use Australian English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date= February 2017}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = protected | name = Bangham Conservation Park | state = sa | iucn_category = III | image = | caption = | image_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|36.6031|S|140.9309|E|format=dms|display=inline,title}}{{cite web|title= Terrestrial Protected Areas of South Australia (see 'DETAIL' tab)|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/d00ca066-1c8c-412a-9e16-2a37647454a7/files/capad2014sa.xlsx|work=CAPAD 2014|publisher=Australian Government, Department of the Environment (DoE) |accessdate=20 June 2016|date=2014}} | force_national_map = | relief = yes | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = left | map_alt = | nearest_town_or_city = [[Naracoorte, South Australia| Naracoorte]]{{cite web|url=http://maps.sa.gov.au/plb/# |title=Search result(s) for Bangham Conservation Park (Record No. SA0004486) with the following layers being selected - "Parcel labels", "Suburbs and Localities", "Hundreds", "Place names (gazetteer)" and "Road labels" |publisher=Government of South Australia |work=Property Location Browser |accessdate=24 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012010923/http://maps.sa.gov.au/plb/ |archivedate=12 October 2016 }} | area = 8.69 | area_footnotes = {{cite web|title=Protected Areas Information System - reserve list (as of 11 July 2016)|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/sharedassets/public/park_management/protected-areas-reserve-list-30june2016-gen.pdf |publisher=Department of Environment Water and Natural Resources|date=11 July 2016 |accessdate=14 July 2016}} | established = {{start date|1973|011|22|df=y}} | established_footnotes = {{cite journal|title= NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE ACT, 1972: HUNDRED OF GEEGEELA—BANGHAM CONSERVATION PARK CONSTITUTED |journal=The South Australian Government Gazette |date=22 November 1973 |page= 2968|url= http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/other/sa_gazette/1973/59/2968.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2017 |publisher=Government of South Australia}} | visitation_num = ‘low level’ | visitation_year = 1992 | visitation_footnotes ={{Citation | author1=South Australia. National Parks and Wildlife Service. South East District | author2=Sutherland, Andrea | author3=South Australia. National Parks and Wildlife Service | title=Small parks of the upper South East management plans, South East, South Australia | publication-date=1992 | publisher=Dept. of Environment and Planning |url=https://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/sharedassets/public/park_management/parks_pdfs_sml_prks_uppr_se_mp.pdf |pages=8-10 |isbn=978-0-7308-2665-1 }} | managing_authorities = [[Department of Environment and Water (South Australia)|Department of Environment and Water]] | url = | footnotes = }} '''Bangham Conservation Park''' is a [[protected area]] in the Australian state of [[South Australia]] located in the state’s [[Limestone Coast]] in the gazetted locality of [[Bangham, South Australia| Bangham]] about {{convert|45|km}} north-east of the town centre in [[Naracoorte, South Australia| Naracoorte]]. The conservation park occupies land in section 4 and Allotment 1 of Deposited Plan 78796 in the [[Lands administrative divisions of South Australia|cadastral unit]] of the [[Hundred of Geegeela]] which is bounded by the Bordertown-Frances Road on its western side, a road on its southern side and the Bordertown – Naracoorte railway line on its eastern side. As of 1992, access tracks had been constructed along the northern and eastern boundaries of section 4 while an easement for an electricity transmission line passed through the western side of the conservation park.{{cite journal|title= National Parks and Wildlife (Bangham Conservation Park) Proclamation 2010 [Published in the Gazette on 18 February 2010 at page 822] |work=South Australian Proclamations and Notices |date=18 February 2010 |page= |url= http://www5.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/proc/npawcpp2010575/ |accessdate=24 February 2017 |publisher= Australasian Legal Information Institute}} The land originally gained protected area status in 1973, when section 4 was gazetted as the Bangham Conservation Park. In 2010, additional land consisting of Allotment 1 of Deposited Plan 78796 was added to the north side of the conservation park. The land was offered in 1971 to the [[government of South Australia]] for [[conservation (ethic)|conservation purposes]]. At the time, it consisted of {{convert|6.76|km2}} of “native scrub” and {{convert|1.25|km2}} of “cleared land” with the majority of the latter occupying its south-east corner. A subsequent study revealed that the land was used by [[red-tailed black cockatoo]]s which at the time had “limited distribution” in South Australia and which made the land “particularly suitable for conservation purposes.” In 1992, the conservation park was described as follows:
(It) is characterised by an undulating plain of [[Tertiary]] sand with local [[Rust (color)|ferruginous]] cappings overlain by easterly trending dunes and sheets of [[Aeolian processes|aeolian sand]]. Occasional [[sinkhole]]s and small depressions are caused by solution of the underlying [[limestone]]. Soils … are generally bleached, deep acid sands with a yellow-grey B horizon.
As of 1982, vegetation within the conservation park consisted of the following three major plant associations - a “open forest - woodland“ of [[Eucalyptus leucoxylon|South Australian blue gum]], [[river red gum]] in “areas subject to inundation” and a “open forest - low open forest” of [[Eucalyptus baxteri|brown stringybark]]. As of 1992, visitation to the conservation park was described as “low level of mainly local use with occasional visits from further afield by field naturalists and bird observers” and that no facilities had been provided for visitors. The conservation park is classified as an [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|IUCN]] [[IUCN protected area categories#Category III — Natural Monument or Feature|Category III protected area]]. ==See also== *[[Protected areas of South Australia]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.protectedplanet.net/24290 Webpage for the Bangham Conservation Park on the Protected Planet website] *[http://www.birdssa.asn.au/location/bangham-conservation-park/ Webpage for the Bangham Conservation Park on the Birds SA website] {{Protected areas of South Australia|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Conservation parks of South Australia]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1973]] [[Category:1973 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Limestone Coast]]

{{cleanup rewrite|the article reads like school essay, it should be founded on a secondary ref|date=April 2018}} {{buzzword|date=April 2018}} {{refimprove science|date=April 2018}} A '''bio-battery''' is an energy storing device that is powered by [[organic compounds]], usually being [[glucose]], such as the glucose in human blood. When [[enzymes]] in human bodies break down glucose, several electrons and protons are released. Therefore, by using enzymes to break down glucose, bio-batteries directly receive energy from glucose. These batteries then store this energy for later use. This concept is almost identical to how both plants and many animals obtain energy. Although the batteries are still being tested before being commercially sold, several research teams and engineers are working to further advance the development of these batteries.
== Workings ==
Like any battery, bio-batteries consist of an [[anode]], [[cathode]], [[separator (electricity)|separator]] and [[electrolyte]] with each component layered on top of another. Anodes and cathodes are the positive and negative areas on a battery that allow electrons to flow in and out. The anode is located at the top of the battery and the cathode is located at the bottom of the battery. Anodes allow current to flow in from outside the battery, whereas cathodes allow current to flow out from the battery.
Between the anode and the cathode lies the electrolyte which contains a separator. The main function of the separator is to keep the cathode and anode separated, to avoid electrical short circuits. This system as a whole, allows for a flow of protons (H+) and electrons (e-) which ultimately generates electricity.<ref name="northeastern"/>
In the anode the sugar is broken down, producing both electrons and protons.
Glucose → [[Gluconolactone]] + 2H<sup>+</sup> + 2e<sup>−</sup>
These electrons and protons produced now play an important role in creating energy. They travel through the electrolyte, where the separator redirects electrons to go through the mediator to get to the cathode.{{cn|date=April 2018}} On the other hand, protons are redirected to go through the separator to get to the cathode side of the battery.<ref name="northeastern"/>
The cathode then consists of an oxidation reduction reaction. This reaction uses the protons and electrons, with the addition of oxygen gas, to produce water.
O<sub>2</sub> +4H<sup>+</sup> + 4e<sup>−</sup> → 2H<sub>2</sub>O
==Advantages==
A significant advantage that bio-batteries have in comparison to other batteries is their ability to allow an instant recharge.<ref name="CFDRC"/> In other words, through a constant supply of sugar, or glucose, bio batteries are able to continuously keep themselves charged without an external power supply. Bio batteries are also a source of non-flammable, and non-toxic fuel. This provides a clean alternative renewable power source.<ref name=CFDRC>{{cite web|title=Bio-Battery: Clean, Renewable Power Source|url=http://www.cfdrc.com/bio/bio-battery|publisher=CFD Research Corporation|accessdate=17 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102180433/http://www.cfdrc.com/bio/bio-battery|archivedate=2 November 2012|df=}}</ref>
==Disadvantages==
Compared to conventional batteries, such as lithium batteries, bio-batteries are less likely to retain most of their energy.<ref name=advantages>{{cite web|title=CELLULOSE-BASED BATTERIES|url=http://advantage-environment.com/uncategorized/cellulose-based-batteries/|publisher=Confederation of Swedish Enterprise}}</ref> This causes a problem when it comes to long term usage and storage of energy for these batteries. However, researchers are continuing to develop the battery in order to make it a more practical replacement for current batteries and sources of energy.<ref name="advantages"/>
==Application==
Although biobatteries are not ready for commercial sale, several research teams and engineers are working to further advance the development of these batteries.<ref name="CFDRC"/> [[Sony]] has created a bio battery that gives an output power of 50 mW (milliwatts). This output is enough to power approximately one MP3 player.<ref name=northeastern>{{cite web |author1=Kannan, Renugopalakrishnan |author2=Filipek, Audette |author3=Li, Munukutla |title=Bio-Batteries and Bio-Fuel Cells: Leveraging on Electronic Charge Transfer Proteins |url=http://www.northeastern.edu/bionano/bio-pdfs/J%20N%20N%20%20%20%20Bio%20Fuel%20Cells%20and%20Bio%20Batteries.pdf |publisher=American Scientific Publishers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304203347/http://www.northeastern.edu/bionano/bio-pdfs/J%20N%20N%20%20%20%20Bio%20Fuel%20Cells%20and%20Bio%20Batteries.pdf |archivedate=2011-03-04 |df= }}</ref> In the coming years, Sony plans to take bio batteries to market, starting with toys and devices that require a small amount of energy.<ref name="advantages"/> Several other research facilities, such as Stanford and Northeastern, are also in the process of researching and experimenting with bio batteries as an alternative source of energy. Since there is glucose in human blood, some research facilities are also looking towards the medical benefits of bio-batteries and their possible functions in human bodies. Although this has yet to be further tested, research continues on the subject surrounding both the material/device and medical usage of bio-batteries.
==Bacteria== There has been a recent interest in using bacteria to generate and store electricity. In 2013, researchers found that [[E. coli]] is a good candidate for a living biobattery because its metabolism may sufficiently convert glucose into energy thus produce electricity.<ref>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/07/130717051733.htm</ref> Through the combination of differing genes it is possible to optimise efficient electrical production of the organism. Bacterial bio-batteries have great potential in that they can generate electricity rather than just storing it and also that they may contain less toxic or corrosive substances than [[hydrochloric acid]], and [[sulphuric acid]].
Another bacteria of interest is a newly discovered bacterium, [[Shewanella oneidensis]], dubbed "Electric Bacteria" which can reduce toxic manganese ions and turn them into food.<ref>http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/microbes-breathe-and-eat-electricity-make-us-re-think-what-life-180953883/?no-ist</ref> In the process it also generates electrical current, and this current is carried along tiny wires made of bacterial appendages called bacterial nano-wires. This network of bacteria and interconected wires creates a vast bacterial biocircuit unlike anything previously known to science. Besides generating electricity it also has the ability to store electric charge,<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=21981730 | doi=10.1021/es2025214 | volume=45 | title=Transient storage of electrical charge in biofilms of Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 growing in a microbial fuel cell | year=2011 | journal=Environ. Sci. Technol. | pages=10250–6 | last1 = Uría | first1 = N | last2 = Muñoz Berbel | first2 = X | last3 = Sánchez | first3 = O | last4 = Muñoz | first4 = FX | last5 = Mas | first5 = J| bibcode=2011EnST...4510250U }}</ref> which makes it of special interest to create a bacterial biobattery which can be used for things such as charging a cellphone or computer.<ref>http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2299318/Maybe-clean-energy-isnt-great-Scientists-brink-creating-batteries-produce-electricity-bacteria.html,</ref>
Scientists showed that bacteria could load electrons onto and discharge electrons from microscopic particles of magnetite. Researchers had new experiments with purple bacteria, [[Rhodopseudomonas palustris]], by controlling the amount of light the bacteria was exposed to. This bacteria was able to pull electrons from its surrounding environment. The team changed the light conditions. During the day-time, phototrophic iron-oxidizing bacteria were able to remove electrons from the magnetite discharging it. During the night-time, the bacteria were able to put electrons back onto the magnetite recharging it.<ref name=EAG1 /> During this process, researchers found out that this magnetite could be used to clean up toxic metals. Magnetite can reduce the toxic form of [[chromium]], chromium VI, to the less toxic chromium (III).<ref name="EAG1">{{Cite web |url=http://www.eag.eu.com/about/media/bacteria-can-use-magnetic-particles/ |title=New study shows Bacteria can use magnetic particles to create a ‘natural battery’ |date=27 March 2015}} Press release</ref>
== See also == * [[Paper battery]] * [[Sugar battery]] * [[List of battery types]] * [[Bioelectrochemical reactor]] * [[Shewanella oneidensis]] * [[Bacterial nanowires]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: /* History */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: IEEE Trans. Plasma Science → IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
revision.text:
[[File:Schematic-of-combined-FACs-and-ionospheric-current-systems.png|thumb|300px|Schematic of the Birkeland or Field-Aligned Currents and the ionospheric current systems they connect to, Pedersen and Hall currents. Note that the name "Pederson" is erroneous in this figure.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Le|first=G.|author2=J. A. Slavin|author3=R. J. Strangeway|title=Space Technology 5 observations of the imbalance of regions 1 and 2 field-aligned currents and its implication to the cross-polar cap Pedersen currents|journal=J. Geophys. Res.|year=2010|volume=115|issue=A07202|pages=n/a|doi=10.1029/2009JA014979|bibcode = 2010JGRA..115.7202L }}</ref>]]
A '''Birkeland current''' is a set of currents that flow along [[geomagnetic]] field lines connecting the Earth’s [[magnetosphere]] to the Earth's high latitude [[ionosphere]]. In the Earth’s magnetosphere, the currents are driven by the [[solar wind]] and [[interplanetary magnetic field]] and by bulk motions of plasma through the magnetosphere (convection indirectly driven by the interplanetary environment). The strength of the Birkeland currents changes with activity in the magnetosphere (e.g. during [[substorm]]s). Small scale variations in the upward current sheets (downward flowing electrons) accelerate magnetospheric electrons which, when they reach the upper atmosphere, create the [[Aurora (astronomy)|Auroras]] Borealis and Australis. In the high latitude ionosphere (or auroral zones), the Birkeland currents close through the region of the auroral [[electrojet]], which flows perpendicular to the local magnetic field in the ionosphere. The Birkeland currents occur in two pairs of field-aligned current sheets. One pair extends from noon through the dusk sector to the midnight sector. The other pair extends from noon through the dawn sector to the midnight sector. The sheet on the high latitude side of the auroral zone is referred to as the Region 1 current sheet and the sheet on the low latitude side is referred to as the Region 2 current sheet.
The currents were predicted in 1908 by Norwegian explorer and physicist [[Kristian Birkeland]], who undertook expeditions north of the [[Arctic Circle]] to study the aurora. He rediscovered, using simple magnetic field measurement instruments, that when the aurora appeared the needles of magnetometers changed direction, confirming the findings of [[Anders Celsius]] and assistant [[Olof Hjorter]] more than a century before. This could only imply that currents were flowing in the atmosphere above. He theorized that somehow the Sun emitted a cathode ray,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Birkeland|first=Kristian|title=Sur les rayons cathodiques sous l'action de forces magnetiques intenses|journal=Archives des Sciences Physiques|year=1896|volume=4|pages=497–512}}</ref><ref name="NAPE">{{cite book|last=Birkeland|first=Kristian|title=The Norwegian Aurora Polaris Expedition 1902-1903|year=1908|publisher=H. Aschehoug & Co|location=New York and Christiania (now Oslo)|url=https://archive.org/details/norwegianaurorap01chririch}} out-of-print, full text online</ref> and corpuscles from what is now known as a [[solar wind]] entered the Earth’s magnetic field and created currents, thereby creating the aurora. This view was scorned by other researchers,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schuster|first=Arthur|title=(article title N/A)|journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society A]]|date=March 1912|volume=85|issue=575|pages=44–50|doi=10.1098/rspa.1911.0019|bibcode=1911RSPSA..85...44S}}</ref> but in 1967 a satellite, launched into the auroral region, showed that the currents posited by Birkeland existed. In honour of him and his theory these currents are named Birkeland currents. A good description of the discoveries by Birkeland is given in the book by Jago.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jago|first=Lucy|title=The Northern Lights: How One Man Sacrificed Love, Happiness and Sanity to Unlock the Secrets of Space|year=2001|publisher=Knopf|isbn=978-0-375-40980-6|pages=320}}</ref>
Professor Emeritus of the Alfvén Laboratory in Sweden, [[Carl-Gunne Fälthammar]] wrote:<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fälthammar|first=Carl-Gunne|title=Magnetosphere-Ionosphere Interactions. Near Earth Manifestations of the Plasma Universe|journal=IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science|date=Dec 1986|volume=PS-14|issue=6|pages=616–628|doi=10.1109/TPS.1986.4316613|bibcode = 1986ITPS...14..616F }}</ref> "A reason why Birkeland currents are particularly interesting is that, in the plasma forced to carry them, they cause a number of plasma physical processes to occur ([[Waves in plasmas|waves]], [[Instability|instabilities]], fine structure formation). These in turn lead to consequences such as [[Plasma acceleration|acceleration of charged particles]], both positive and negative, and element separation (such as preferential ejection of oxygen ions). Both of these classes of phenomena should have a general astrophysical interest far beyond that of understanding the space environment of our own Earth." [[File:Birkeland-anode-globe-fig259.jpg|thumb|300px|Auroral-like Birkeland currents created by scientist [[Kristian Birkeland]] in his [[terrella]], featuring a magnetised anode globe in an evacuated chamber.]]
==Characteristics== Auroral Birkeland currents carry about 100,000 [[ampere]]s during quiet times<ref>{{cite journal|last=Suzuki|first=Akira|author2=Naoshi Fukushima|title=Space current around the earth obtained with Ampère's law applied to the MAGSAT orbit and data|journal=Earth Planets Space|year=1998|volume=50|issue=1|pages=43–56|url=http://www.terrapub.co.jp/journals/EPS/pdf/5001/50010043.pdf|bibcode = 1998EP&S...50...43S|doi=10.1186/bf03352085}}</ref> and more than 1 million amperes during geomagnetically disturbed times.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=B. J.|author2=J. b. Gary|author3=T. A. Potemra|author4=R. A. Frahm|author5=J. R. Sharber|author6=J. D. Winningham|title=UARS observations of Birkeland currents and Joule heating rates for the November 4, 1993, storm|journal=J. Geophys. Res.|year=1998|volume=103|issue=A11|pages=26323–35|doi=10.1029/98JA01236|bibcode=1998JGR...10326323A}}</ref> Birkeland had estimated currents "at heights of several hundred kilometres, and strengths of up to a million amperes" in 1908.<ref name=NAPE /> The ionospheric currents that connect the field-aligned currents heat up the upper atmosphere due to the finite conductivity of the ionosphere. The heat (also known as [[Joule heating|Joule heat]]) is transferred from the ionospheric plasma to the gas of the upper atmosphere, which consequently rises and increases drag on low-altitude satellites.
Birkeland currents can also be created in the laboratory with multi-[[terawatt]] [[pulsed power]] generators. The resulting cross-section pattern indicates a hollow beam of electrons in the form of a circle of [[vortices]], a formation called the [[diocotron instability]]<ref>[http://www.aldebaran.cz/astrofyzika/plazma/phenomena_en.html#instab Plasma phenomena - instabilities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528020309/http://www.aldebaran.cz/astrofyzika/plazma/phenomena_en.html |date=2014-05-28 }}</ref> (similar to the [[Kelvin-Helmholtz instability]]), that subsequently leads to filamentation. Such vortices can be seen in aurora as "auroral curls".<ref>[http://www.phys.ucalgary.ca/~trondsen/pai/Curls.html Pseudo-color, white-light images of curl formations in auroral arcs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050503065835/http://www.phys.ucalgary.ca/~trondsen/pai/Curls.html |date=May 3, 2005 }}</ref>
Birkeland currents are also one of a class of plasma phenomena called a [[z-pinch]], so named because the azimuthal magnetic fields produced by the current pinches the current into a filamentary cable. This can also twist, producing a helical pinch that spirals like a twisted or braided rope, and this most closely corresponds to a Birkeland current. Pairs of parallel Birkeland currents will also interact due to [[Ampère's force law]]: parallel Birkeland currents moving in the same direction will attract each other with an electromagnetic force inversely proportional to their distance apart whilst parallel Birkeland currents moving in opposite directions will repel each other. There is also a short-range circular component to the force between two Birkeland currents that is opposite to the longer-range parallel forces.<ref>[http://public.lanl.gov/alp/plasma/EM_forces.html Electromagnetic Forces<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051003211220/http://public.lanl.gov/alp/plasma/EM_forces.html |date=October 3, 2005 }}</ref>
Electrons moving along a Birkeland current may be accelerated by a plasma [[Double layer (plasma)|double layer]]. If the resulting electrons approach the speed of light, they may subsequently produce a [[Bennett pinch]], which in a magnetic field causes the electrons to spiral and emit [[synchrotron radiation]] that may include [[radio]], [[visible light]], [[x-rays]], and [[gamma rays]].
==History== [[File:Birkeland-currents.gif|thumb|300px|Kristian Birkeland predicted the auroral electrojets in 1908. He wrote p. 95<ref name="NAPE" /> "the currents there are imagined as having come into existence mainly as a secondary effect of the electric corpuscles from the sun drawn in out of space, and thus far come under the second of the possibilities mentioned above". And p. 105, "Fig. 50a represents those in which the current-directions at the storm-centre are directed westwards, and 50b those in which the currents move eastwards".]]
After Kristian Birkeland first suggested in 1908 that "currents there [in the aurora] are imagined as having come into existence mainly as a secondary effect of the electric corpuscles from the sun drawn in out of space,"<ref name="NAPE" /> the story appears to have become mired in politics.<ref>{{cite journal| first=Stephen G.| last=Brush| title=Alfvén's Programme in Solar System Physics| journal=IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science| volume=20| issue=6|date=December 1992| doi=10.1109/27.199495| pages=577–589|bibcode = 1992ITPS...20..577B }}</ref> Birkeland's ideas were generally ignored in favor of an alternative theory from British mathematician [[Sydney Chapman (astronomer)|Sydney Chapman]].<ref>S. Chapman and J. Bartels, ‘’Geomagnetism,’’ Vol. 1 and 2, Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1940.</ref>
In 1939, the Swedish Engineer and plasma physicist [[Hannes Alfvén]] promoted Birkeland's ideas in a paper<ref>Alfvén, Hannes (1939), "Theory of Magnetic Storms and of the Aurorae", K. Sven. ''Vetenskapsakad. Handl''., ser. 3, vol. 18, no. 3, p. 1, 1939. Reprinted in part, with comments by A. J. Dessler and J. Wilcox, in ''Eos, Trans. Am. Geophys. Un''., vol. 51, p. 180, 1970.</ref> published on the generation of the current from the Solar Wind. In 1964 one of Alfvén's colleagues, Rolf Boström, also used field-aligned currents in a new model of [[Electrojet#Auroral Electrojet|auroral electrojets]].<ref name=Bostrom1964>{{cite journal|author=Boström R.|title=A Model of the Auroral Electrojets|journal=J. Geophys. Res.|year=1964|volume=69|issue=23|pages=4983–4999|doi=10.1029/JZ069i023p04983|bibcode=1964JGR....69.4983B}}</ref>
Proof of Birkeland's theory of the aurora only came after a probe was sent into space. The crucial results were obtained from U.S. Navy satellite 1963-38C, launched in 1963 and carrying a [[magnetometer]] above the [[ionosphere]]. In 1966 Alfred Zmuda, J.H. Martin, and F.T.Heuring<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zmuda|first=Alfred|author2=J.H. Martin|author3=F.T.Heuring|last-author-amp=yes|title=Transverse Magnetic Disturbances at 1100 Kilometers in the Auroral Region|journal=J. Geophys. Res.|year=1966|volume=71|issue=21|pages=5033–5045|doi=10.1029/JZ071i021p05033|bibcode=1966JGR....71.5033Z}}</ref> analysed the satellite magnetometer results and reported their findings of magnetic disturbance in the aurora. In 1967 [[Alexander J. Dessler|Alex Dessler]] and graduate student David Cummings wrote an article<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cummings|first=W. D.|author2=A. J. Dessler|title=Field‐Aligned Currents in the Magnetosphere|journal=J. Geophys. Res.|year=1967|volume=72|issue=3|pages=1007–1013|doi=10.1029/JZ072i003p01007|bibcode=1967JGR....72.1007C}}</ref> arguing that Zmuda et al. had detected field-aligned currents. Alfvén subsequently acknowledged<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alfvén|first=Hannes|title=Double layers and circuits in astrophysics|journal=IEEE Trans. Plasma Sci.|year=1986|volume=14|issue=6|pages=779–793|doi=10.1109/TPS.1986.4316626|bibcode=1986ITPS...14..779A }}</ref> that Dessler had "discovered the currents that Birkeland had predicted" and they should be called Birkeland-Dessler currents. 1967 is therefore taken as the date when Birkeland's theory was finally acknowledged to have been vindicated. In 1969 Milo Schield, Alex Dessler and John Freeman<ref>{{cite journal |last=Schields |first=M. |author2=J. Freeman|author3=A. Dessler |title=A Source for Field‐Aligned Currents at Auroral Latitudes|journal=J. Geophys. Res. |year=1969 |volume=74 |issue=1 |pages=247–256 |doi=10.1029/JA074i001p00247 |bibcode = 1969JGR....74..247S }}</ref> used the name "Birkeland currents" for the first time. In 1970 Zmuda, Armstrong and Heuring wrote another paper<ref>{{cite journal |last=Zmuda |first=A. |author2=J. Armstrong|author3=F. Heuring |title=Characteristics of Transverse Magnetic Disturbances Observed at 1100 Kilometers in the Auroral Oval |journal=J. Geophys. Res. |year=1970 |volume=75 |issue=25 |pages=4757–4762 |doi=10.1029/JA075i025p04757 |bibcode = 1970JGR....75.4757Z }}</ref> agreeing that their observations were compatible with field-aligned currents as suggested by Cummings and Dessler and by Boström.<ref name=Bostrom1964 />
==See also== * [[Electromagnetism]] * [[Magnetohydrodynamics]] * [[List of plasma (physics) articles]] * [[Plasma cosmology]] claims that Birkeland currents happen at galactic level and are important in the formation of galaxies
==References== [[File:Magnetic rope.svg|thumb|300px|The complex self-constricting magnetic field lines and current paths in a Birkeland current that may develop in a [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] (Figure 15.3.2, Alfvén and Arrhenius, 1976)<ref>{{cite book|last=Alfvén|first=Hannes|title=Evolution of the Solar System|year=1976|publisher=Scientific and Technical Information Office, National Aeronautics and Space Administration|location=Washington. D.C., USA|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-345/sp345.htm}}</ref>]] {{reflist}}

Geophys. Union, Washington, D.C., {{ISBN|0-87590-976-0}}.
;Journals * Rostoker, G.; Armstrong, J. C.; Zmuda, A. J. (1975), Field-aligned current flow associated with intrusion of the substorm-intensified westward electrojet into the evening sector", ''J. Geophys. Res. '', vol. '''80''', Sept. 1, 1975, p. 3571-3579, {{doi|10.1029/JA080i025p03571}} * Potemra, T. A. "''[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=1988Ap%26SS.144..155P&db_key=AST&data_type=HTML&format=&high=42ca922c9c21187 Birkeland currents in the earth's magnetosphere]''", from a ''[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-abs_connect?db_key=ALL&bibstem=Astrophysics+and+Space+Science&year=1988&volume=144 Special Issue of Astrophysics and Space Science]''" Dedicated to Hannes Alfvén on his 80th Birthday (''Astrophysics and Space Science'', vol. '''144''', no. 1-2, May 1988, p. 155-169, {{doi|10.1007/BF00793179}} * Alfvén, Hannes, [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=1963IAUS...16...35A&db_key=AST&link_type=ABSTRACT&high=42ca922c9c23043 On the Filamentary Structure of the Solar Corona] (1963) ''The Solar Corona''; Proceedings of IAU Symposium no. 16 held at Cloudcroft, New Mexico, U.S.A. 28–30 August 1961. Edited by John Wainwright Evans. International Astronomical Union. Symposium no. 16, Academic Press, New York, 1963., p. 35 * Alfvén, Hannes, [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=1967SoPh....1..220A&db_key=AST&link_type=ABSTRACT&high=42ca922c9c23043 Currents in the Solar Atmosphere and a Theory of Solar Flares] (March 1967) ) ''Solar Physics'', V '''1''', 2, pp. 220–228, {{doi|10.1007/BF00150857}} * Alfvén, Hannes, [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=1967SSRv....7..140A&db_key=AST&link_type=ABSTRACT&high=42ca922c9c23043 On the Importance of Electric Fields in the Magnetosphere and Interplanetary Space] (1967) ''Space Science Reviews'', Volume '''7''', Issue 2-3, pp. 140–148, {{doi|10.1007/BF00215591}} * Carlqvist, P., [http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?1988Ap%26SS.144...73C Cosmic electric currents and the generalized Bennett relation], ''Astrophysics and Space Science'' ({{ISSN|0004-640X}}), vol. '''144''', no. 1-2, p. 73-84. (May 1988) {{doi|10.1007/BF00793173}} * Cloutier, P. A.; Anderson, H. R. [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=1975SSRv...17..563C&db_key=AST&link_type=ABSTRACT&high=42ca922c9c00817 Observations of Birkeland currents] ''Space Science Reviews'', 17, p. 563-587, Mar.-June 1975, {{doi|10.1007/BF00718585}} * Potemra, T. A. [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=1978Ap%26SS..58..207P&db_key=AST&link_type=ABSTRACT&high=42ca922c9c00817 Observation of Birkeland currents with the TRIAD satellite], ''Astrophysics and Space Science'', '''58''', 1, Sept. 1978, {{doi|10.1007/BF00645387}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2014}} [[File:Vertisol.jpg|thumb|upright|Bujeo soil profile]] '''Bujeo''' is a type of [[soil]] found on the countryside of [[Andalusia]] , mainly the area of the [[Guadalquivir]] valley.<ref name="Naylon1975">{{cite book|author=John Naylon|title=Andalusia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VTEuAAAAMAAJ|year=1975|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=12}}</ref>
The color ranges from yellowish brown to olive brown gray and dark gray to almost black, depending on their composition. One of its main features is its columnar structure strong and deep cracks in the dry state when dealing with materials rich in clays expansive. The texture is silty clay to clay. Their pH ranges from neutral to moderately alkaline and organic matter content is generally low.
Because of the way these loamy clay soils "swell in winter and crack deeply in summer", they are called "tierras de bujeo", which literally means "land that moves".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.academia.edu/6067049Riparia_Enviroments_in_Hispania_Ulterior_Baetica_The_Case_of_the_Lagoon_of_La_Janda_and_the_Estuary_of_the_Barbate_River |title=Riparia Environments in Hispania Ulterior |work=academia.edu |accessdate=4 March 2015 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Andalusia]] [[Category:Soil]]

Argument
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox journal | title = Das Argument | cover = | caption = | former_name = <!-- or |former_names= --> | abbreviation = Argument | discipline = <!-- or |subject= --> | peer-reviewed = | language = German | editor = <!-- or |editors= --> | publisher = [[Berlin Institute for Critical Theory]] | country = Germany | history = 1959–present | frequency = 6/year | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSNlabel = | ISSN = 0004-1157 | eISSN = | CODEN = | JSTOR = | LCCN = | OCLC = 1743472 | website = | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = <!-- up to |link5= --> | link2-name = <!-- up to |link5-name= --> | boxwidth = }} '''''Das Argument: Zeitschrift für Philosophie und Sozialwissenschaften''''' (English: ''The Argument: Journal for Philosophy and Social Sciences'') is a German [[academic journal]]. It was established in 1959 as an independent [[West Germany|West German]] journal of predominantly [[Marxism|Marxist]] orientation. It appears six times a year.
==History== The journal emerged from the protests against West German remilitarization. Since 1959, the [[editor-in-chief]] has been the Marxist [[philosophy|philosopher]] [[Wolfgang Fritz Haug]] ([[Free University of Berlin]]). ''Das Argument'' is published by the [[Berlin Institute of Critical Theory]] (InkriT).
== Scope == Each issue of the journal is devoted to a specific theme (e.g., in 2006 these have been "American Vistas", "Politics of Literature", "Female Migrants", "Thinking History Globally" and "Big Contradiction China"). The journal contains a substantial review section which is also derived from the original ''[[Zeitschrift für Sozialforschung]]''. Among the topics covered are: * Philosophy and [[Critical theory|Critical Theory]] * [[Plural Marxism]], [[Western Marxism]], [[Open Marxism]], [[Marxist feminism]] * [[Historiography|Critical History]], analysis of [[capitalism]], [[neoliberalism]]/neoliberal [[mode of production]] and way of life * [[Social sciences]] * [[Social theory]], [[capitalist globalization]], [[transnational class analysis]] * [[Fascism theory]], [[ideology theory]], [[culture theory]] * [[History of modern literature|Literary science]] * History of the [[labor movement]] * [[Ecology]]
==Abstracting and indexing== ''Das Argument'' is abstracted and indexed in:<ref>http://miar.ub.edu/issn/0004-1157</ref> *[[Scopus]] *[[IBZ Online]] *[[Periodicals Index Online]] *[[MLA - Modern Language Association Database]] *[[Philosopher's Index]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * Haug, Wolfgang Fritz: ''[http://www.wolfgangfritzhaug.inkrit.de/documents/argu-inkrit-06wfhx.pdf Zur Neugründung des Arguments]'' * Korte, Peter, ed.: ''30 Jahre Argument, Erfahrungen und Perspektiven, Interviews zu einem Jubiläum'', Argument Verlag, Hamburg 1988.
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.inkrit.de/neuinkrit/index.php/de/das-argument}} {{de icon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Argument, Das}} [[Category:Publications established in 1959]] [[Category:German-language journals]] [[Category:Marxism]] [[Category:Philosophy journals]] [[Category:Bimonthly journals]]
