revision.text:
{{short description|A submerged microcontinent south east of Tasmania}} {{Coord|43.96|S|150.48|E|display=title}} The '''East Tasman Plateau''' is a submerged [[microcontinent]] south east of [[Tasmania]]. Its area is {{convert|50000|km2}}, and it is mostly from {{convert|2500|to|3000|m|ft}} deep.<ref name="Hill">{{cite web|url=http://www.ga.gov.au/corporate_data/37788/Rec2001_040.pdf|title=Geological framework of the South Tasman Rise and East Tasman Plateau|last=Hill|first=P. J.|author2=A. M. G. Moore |year=2001|publisher=Department of Industry, Tourism & Resources|isbn=0642467218|accessdate=5 July 2014}}</ref> It is a circular piece of continental rocks surrounded by oceanic crust. Volcanism occurred there {{Ma|36}}.<ref name=microcon>C. Gaina, R. D. Müller, B. Brown and T. Ishihara: [http://www.geosci.usyd.edu.au/users/dietmar/Pdf/Gaina_etal_GSA_SpecPap2003.pdf ''Microcontinent formation around Australia''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723174911/http://www.geosci.usyd.edu.au/users/dietmar/Pdf/Gaina_etal_GSA_SpecPap2003.pdf |date=2008-07-23 }} in Geological Society of Australia Special Publication 22, 2001 page 400–405</ref> The East Tasman Plateau is separated from the island of Tasmania by {{convert|100|km}} of deeper water, and the East Tasman Saddle is a higher ridge connecting the plateau to the [[Freycinet Peninsula]] region of the Tasmanian East Coast.<ref name="Hill"/> This ridge runs north west from the plateau.<ref name="Hill"/> South-west of the plateau is the [[L'Atalante Depression]].<ref name="Exon1997"/>
==Tectonics== Prior to tectonic rifting, the East Tasman Plateau microcontinent was attached to the southeast of Tasmania and the north east of the South Tasman Rise.<ref name=microcon/> To the northeast, east and south east of the plateau was the Lord Howe Rise.<ref name="Gaina1998">{{cite journal|last=Gaina|first=Carmen|author2=Dietmar R. Müller|author3=Jean-Yves Royer|author4=Joann Stock|author5=Jeanne Hardebeck|author6=Phil Symonds|year=1998|title=The tectonic history of the Tasman Sea: A puzzle with 13 pieces|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|volume=103|issue=B6|page=12413|issn=0148-0227|doi=10.1029/98JB00386|url=http://www.earthbyte.org/people/dietmar/Pdf/Gaina_etal_TasmanSea_JGR1998.pdf|accessdate=10 July 2014|bibcode=1998JGR...10312413G|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423124250/http://www.earthbyte.org/people/dietmar/Pdf/Gaina_etal_TasmanSea_JGR1998.pdf|archivedate=23 April 2012|df=}}</ref> In the [[Cretaceous]] period, the continental breakup of [[Gondwana]] started near [[Geology of Tasmania|Tasmania]]. About {{Ma|83}} a rift entered the east coast of Tasmania from the south and split off the [[Lord Howe Rise]]<ref name=microcon/> from the [[South Tasman Rise]] to the west.<ref name="Exon1997"/> [[Sea floor spreading]] continued to move this continental sliver away to the east from Tasmania and Australia, and the rift jumped into the Lord Howe Rise and separated off the East Tasman Plateau.<ref name=microcon/> The detachment of the East Tasman Plateau from the Lord Howe Rise has left a large gulf on the west side of the Lord Howe Rise around 38°S 162°E where it used to be.<ref name="Gaina1998"/>
In the late Cretaceous the East Tasman Plateau was at 65°S and it moved north to 60°S in early Oligocene.<ref name=exon03>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/238585409_Late_Cretaceous_to_Oligocene_Geological_History_of_the_East_Tasman_Plateau_a_Key_Piece_of_the_Tasmanian_Gateway_Story|title=Late Cretaceous to Oligocene Geological History of the East Tasman Plateau, a Key Piece of the Tasmanian Gateway Story - ResearchGate|last=Exon|first=N. F.|date=December 2003|work=AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|accessdate=7 July 2014}}</ref>
==Geology== The geology of the East Tasman Plateau includes early hard continental type rocks, volcanic rocks which are part of sea mounts, and marine sediments deposited since it was below sea level.
The earliest continental East Tasman Plateau rocks that have been brought to the surface of the sea are of [[Neoproterozoic]] age, and include [[gneiss]], [[rhyolite]], [[quartzite]], sandstone, [[ferricrete]], and metamorphosed sediments.<ref name="Exon1997">{{cite journal|last=Exon|first=N. F.|author2=R. F. Berry |author3=A. J. Crawford |author4=P. J. Hill |year=1997|title=Geological evolution of the East Tasman Plateau, a continental fragment southeast of Tasmania|journal=Australian Journal of Earth Sciences|volume=44|issue=5|pages=597–608|issn=0812-0099|doi=10.1080/08120099708728339}}</ref>
The eastern edge of the plateau facing the Tasman Basin is steep, dropping more than {{convert|1000|m}} and composed of granite.<ref name="Hill"/>
Sediments on the East Tasman Plateau start with silty clay from [[Maastrichtian]] to Eocene. These were deposited in shallow sea water.<ref name="Hill"/> The [[microfossil]]s found in these layers include spores, pollen from coniferous forests, and [[dinocyst]]s.<ref name=exon03/> The pollen showed that the climate was humid, with cool winters.<ref name=exon03/> From early to mid Eocene, 55 to 37 Ma, the climate on nearby land was uniform, wet and cool and supported angiosperm forests.<ref name=exon03/> During the mid Eocene microfossils include [[diatom]]s.<ref name=exon03/> Above this in the stratigraphic record is [[glauconite]] containing siltstone deposited at the end of the Eocene.<ref name=exon03/> This material was due to condensed sedimentation due to the added water from the current.<ref name=exon03/> During this period around 36 million years ago the plateau started sinking to a depth of {{convert|300|m}}.<ref name="Hill"/> After this there was a gap in the deposition, due to the opening of the Southern Ocean between the Australian Continent and Antarctica. A seaway carrying the strong [[Antarctic Circumpolar Current]] developed. The current eroded part of the surface, and stopped the sediments from the land masses from reaching it. During Oligocene to mid Miocene there were oceanic deposits of clay and calcareous ooze.<ref name="Hill"/> Microfossils from this time include [[foraminifer]]s.<ref name=exon03/> After this the circumpolar current strengthened and only ooze deposited.<ref name="Hill"/> The current rate of buildup of ooze on the seabed on the plateau is about {{convert|0.01|mm}} per year which is quite slow.<ref name="Nees">{{cite web|url=http://people.rses.anu.edu.au/dedeckker_p/pubs/111.pdf|title=A stable—isotope record for the Late Quaternary from the East Tasman Plateau|last=Nees|first=Stephan |author2=I Martinez |author3=P De Decker |author4=M Ayress|year=1994|work=Evolution of the Tasman Sea Basin|publisher=Balkema|pages=197–202|accessdate=5 July 2014|location=Rotterdam}}</ref> The sinking has been at the rate of {{convert|1|km}} in 10 million years (0.1 mm/year), so the buildup of sediments is not keeping pace with submergence.<ref name="Hill"/>
After the deposition of sediments, the sediment has been modified by [[phosphatisation]] and the formation of [[ferromanganese crust]]s.<ref name="Quilty1997">{{cite journal|last=Quilty|first=P. G.|year=1997|title=Eocene and younger biostratigraphy and lithofacies of the Cascade Seamount, East Tasman Plateau, southwest Pacific Ocean|journal=Australian Journal of Earth Sciences|volume=44|issue=5|pages=655–665|issn=0812-0099|doi=10.1080/08120099708728343}}</ref>
===Paleoclimate=== Carbonate-clumped isotope thermometry uses the carbon-13 and oxygen-18 isotope levels in carbonates to determine the sea temperature. This is in addition to the microfossils, which give a temperature clue as different organisms live in different water temperatures. The sediment cores from the East Tasman Plateau give a history of the temperature of the [[Southern Ocean]] and are valuable in seeing the limits of climate change in the future. Water temperature on the Plateau has been as high as {{convert|22|°C}}.<ref name="Dvorsky">{{cite web|url=http://io9.com/ancient-antarctica-was-as-warm-as-todays-florida-and-ca-1566063244|title=Ancient Antarctica Was As Warm As Today's Florida And California|last=Dvorsky|first=George|date=22 April 2014|work=[[Io9]]|accessdate=11 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Douglas2014">{{cite journal|last=Douglas|first=P. M. J.|author2=H. P. Affek |author3=L. C. Ivany |author4=A. J. P. Houben |author5=W. P. Sijp |author6=A. Sluijs |author7=S. Schouten |author8=M. Pagani |year=2014|title=Pronounced zonal heterogeneity in Eocene southern high-latitude sea surface temperatures|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=111|issue=18|pages=6582–6587|issn=0027-8424|doi=10.1073/pnas.1321441111 |pmid=24753570 |pmc=4020054|bibcode=2014PNAS..111.6582D}}</ref>
==Cascade Seamount== The '''Cascade Seamount''' is an [[seamount|undersea mountain]] which has a height from its base higher than those on Tasmania. The peak of Cascade Seamount is currently {{convert|598|m}} deep.<ref name="Quilty2001"/> The top of the seamount is fairly flat and domed, but once down to {{convert|900|m|abbr=on}} deep the sides slope off very steeply.<ref name="Quilty2001"/> The Cascade Seamount is a volcano formed during the [[Late Eocene]] period as a result of the [[Balleny mantle plume]].<ref name="Exon1997"/> This volcano has produced [[volcanic breccia]], [[hyaloclastite]] and [[alkali olivine basalt]].<ref name="Exon1997"/> The extra weight of the seamount isostatically depressed the adjacent plateau to form a basin. The basin filled with up to {{convert|1000|m|abbr=on}} of sediment during Late Eocene, and [[early Oligocene]], and another {{convert|500|m|abbr=on}} of [[calcareous ooze]] and chalk during [[late Oligocene]].<ref name="Exon1997"/> Originally the volcano was more than {{convert|400|m|abbr=on}} above sea level. The age is confirmed by [[foraminifera]] microfossils [[Chiloguembelina cubensis]], [[Globigerapsis index]], [[Globigerapsis rubriformis]], [[Subbotina angiporoides]] and [[Subbotina linaperta]] found in the sediment on the volcano. This sediment settled in shallow water.<ref name="Quilty2001">{{cite journal|last=Quilty|first=P. G.|year=2001|title=Late Eocene foraminifers and palaeoenvironment, Cascade Seamount, southwest Pacific Ocean: implications for seamount subsidence and Australia-Antarctica Eocene correlation|journal=Australian Journal of Earth Sciences|volume=48|issue=5|pages=633–641|issn=0812-0099|doi=10.1046/j.1440-0952.2001.485886.x}}</ref>
The Cascade Seamount is part of a chain of volcanic seamounts that extend south to the [[Balleny Islands]] near Antarctica.<ref name="Lanyon1993">{{cite journal|last=Lanyon|first=Ruth|author2=Rick Varne |author3=Anthony J. Crawford |year=1993|title=Tasmanian Tertiary basalts, the Balleny plume, and opening of the Tasman Sea (southwest Pacific Ocean)|journal=Geology|volume=21|issue=6|page=555|issn=0091-7613|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1993)021<0555:TTBTBP>2.3.CO;2}}</ref>
High frequency [[echogram]]s show that the top of the seamount is covered in sediment, but that the steep slopes are rocky. There is possibly a debris flow on the east flank.<ref name="Melissa">{{cite web|url=http://geohab.org/conferences/2002-moss-landing/2002-moss-landing-agenda-abstracts/|title=Acoustic Sea floor Mapping of Southeast Australia|last=Melissa|first=E.|author2=Daniell, James J. |author3=Harris, Peter T. |author4=Heap, Andrew D. |work=2002 Moss Landing – Agenda & Abstracts GEOHAB|accessdate=11 July 2014}}</ref>
The name for Cascade Seamount has also been called '''Cascade Guyot'''. The feature was discovered in 1944, and appeared on chart BA214 in 1954. It was named after the [[Cascade Brewery]].<ref name="scufn">{{cite web|url=http://www.gebco.net/about_us/meetings_and_minutes/documents/gebco_scufn_14_report.pdf|title=Fourteenth Meeting of the GEBCO Sub-Committee on Undersea Feature Names (SCUFN)|date=20 April 2001|page=25|accessdate=13 July 2014|location=Tokyo}}</ref>
==Fauna== Above the sea at this location typical Southern Ocean animals are found such as several kinds of [[whales]], [[albatross]] and [[petrel]]s. Species detected include [[Diomedea exulans]], [[Diomedea royal]], [[Diomedea sanfordi]], [[Euphausia frigida]], [[Fregetta tropica]], [[Limacina retroversa]], [[Oceanites oceanicus]], [[Oithona similis]], [[Pachyptila belcheri]], [[Pachyptila crassirostris]], [[Pachyptila turtur]], [[Pachyptila vittata]], [[Pelagodroma marina]], [[Phoebetria fusca]], [[Phoebetria palpebrata]], [[Procellaria aequinoctialis]], [[Pterodroma cookilaria]], [[Pterodroma lessonii]], [[Pterodroma leucoptera]], [[Pterodroma macroptera]], [[Pterodroma macroptera]], [[Pterodroma mollis]], [[Pterodroma neglecta]], [[Puffinus assimilis]], [[Puffinus tenuirostris]], [[Thalassarche bulleri]], [[Thalassarche cauta]], [[Thalassarche melanophrys]], and [[Thysanoessa macrura]].<ref name="ant">{{cite web|url=https://data.aad.gov.au/aadc/biodiversity/species_near_place.cfm?type=Fauna&lat=-43.9167&lon=150.3833&offset=1.0 |title=Antarctic Taxa – Biodiversity database |accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref>
Molluscs found on the Cascade Seamount include [[Cuspidaria brazieri]] (Brazier’s spoon-shell), [[Cuspidaria erma]] (noble spoon-shell), [[Veprichlamys perillustris]] (shining scallop), [[Fusitriton magellanicus retiolus]] (Magellanic rock-whelk), and [[Sassia kampyla]] (curved rock-whelk).<ref name="Grave">{{cite web|url=http://www.molluscsoftasmania.net/Locality%20pages/Southern%20Ocean%20-%20Cascade%20Seamount%20-%20Southern%20Surveyor%20Stn%2068.html|title=Southern Ocean - Cascade Seamount - Southern Surveyor Stn 68|last=Grave|first=Simon|work=A Guide to the seashells and other marine molluscs of Tasmania|publisher=Taroona Scientific|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref> The deep water sea star [[Novodinia australis]] has been found on the Cascade Seamount.<ref name="Rowe">{{cite web|url=http://biocache.ala.org.au/occurrences/3777daad-d00a-4d8c-86c5-4465699d3cd0|title=Record: Invertebrates - Marine & Other:J.21714 Occurrence record|last=Rowe|first=Frank W. E.|work=Atlas of Living Australia|publisher=Australian Museum|accessdate=12 July 2014}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Extra reading== *{{cite journal|last=Fuller|first=Mike|author2=Yannick Touchard |year=2004|title=On the magnetostratigraphy of the East Tasman Plateau Timing of the opening of the Tasmanian Gateway and paleoenvironmental changes|volume=151|pages=63–78|issn=0065-8448|doi=10.1029/151GM05|bibcode=2004GMS...151...63F|journal=Geophysical Monograph Series}} *{{cite journal|last=Schellenberg|first=Stephen A.|author2=Henk Brinkhuis |author3=Catherine E. Stickley |author4=Michael Fuller |author5=Frank T. Kyte |author6=Graham L. Williams |year=2004|title=The Cretaceous/Paleogene transition on the East Tasman Plateau, southwestern Pacific|volume=151|pages=93–112|issn=0065-8448|doi=10.1029/151GM07 |bibcode=2004GMS...151...93S |journal=Geophysical Monograph Series}} *{{cite journal|last=Dietmar Müller|first=R.|author2=Carmen Gaina |author3=Walter R. Roest |author4=David Lundbek Hansen |year=2001|title=A recipe for microcontinent formation|journal=Geology|volume=29|issue=3|page=203|issn=0091-7613|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(2001)029<0203:ARFMF>2.0.CO;2}} explanation of formation

revision.text:
[[File:Slovenia-map-CIA.png|thumb|250px|right| Location]] [[Total primary energy supply]] (TPES) in [[Slovenia]] was 6.67 [[tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] in 2014. In the same year, electricity consumption was 13.87 TWh.<ref name=iea2014 />
Electricity generation is mainly from nuclear power, hydroelectricity (each at 36.5%) and coal (21.6%). Other minor sources include solar PV, biofuels and natural gas. Slovenia has a significant import and export of electricity, with about 16% of the generation as net exports in 2014.<ref name=iea2014>{{cite web|title=IEA - Report|url=https://www.iea.org/statistics/statisticssearch/report/?year=2014&country=Slovenia&product=ElectricityandHeat|website=www.iea.org|accessdate=9 March 2017}}</ref>
Slovenia is a net energy importer, importing all its oil products (mainly for the transport sector) and natural gas.
== Overview == Slovenia imported 49% of its energy use in 2009.<ref>[http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2010/key_stats_2010.pdf IEA Key energy statistics 2010] IEA Key stats 2010 page 52</ref>

includes energy losses </small><ref name=Sverigetab49>[http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=/Broschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f Energy in Sweden 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016045634/http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=%2FBroschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f |date=October 16, 2013 }}. Facts and figures. The Swedish Energy Agency. Table 8 Losses in nuclear power stations Table 9 Nuclear power brutto</ref> <small>2012R = CO2 calculation criteria changed, numbers updated </small> |}
== Electricity == In 2008, electricity use per million person in Slovenia was 6.1 TWh compared to [[Electricity sector in Spain|Spain]] 6.0 TWh. or [[Electricity sector in the United Kingdom|Britain]] 5.7 TWh.<ref name="IEA2010">[http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2010/key_stats_2010.pdf IEA Key energy statistics 2010] Page: Country specific indicator numbers from page 48</ref>
== Renewable energy == In Slovenia's forecast{{cn|date=September 2015}}, renewables satisfy about 40% of the country’s electricity consumption in 2020{{cn|date=September 2015}}. Slovenia is the EU country with the smallest forecast penetration of [[wind power]] in 2020: 1.3% of electricity consumption, while the Irish action plan shows wind meeting over 36% of the country’s electricity demand. Slovenia has intention to cover its EU [[renewable energy]] obligations 6.1TWh (2020) mainly with [[hydro power]] 5.1 TWh and [[biomass]] 0.7 TWh. According to [[EWEA]]’s calculations by 2020 wind could cover 6% - 9% of electricity demand. The newly adopted feed-in tariff limiting support to projects of 5 MW and under may be hindering perspectives for wind power development.<ref>[http://www.ewea.org/fileadmin/ewea_documents/documents/publications/reports/EWEA_EU_Energy_Policy_to_2050.pdf EU Energy Policy to 2050] EWEA March 2011</ref>
==Climate change==
1990 emissions were 20Mt CO2<sup>eq</sup> [[Kyoto protocol]] target is reduction of 2Mt (-8%).<ref>[http://www.ewea.org/fileadmin/ewea_documents/documents/publications/reports/20110909_ClimateReport.pdf Wind energy and EU climate policy Achieving 30% lower emissions by 2020] EWEA October 2011 p. 39</ref>
== See also == {{Commons category}} {{Portal|Energy|Sustainable development|Slovenia}} *[[Nuclear power in Slovenia]] *[[Renewable energy by country]] ==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{infobox book | | name = Evolution | title_orig = | translator = | image = StephenBaxter evolution.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Stephen Baxter (author)|Stephen Baxter]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[Science fiction]] novel | publisher = [[Orion Publishing Group]] | release_date = 4 February 2003 | media_type = Print (hardback & paperback) | pages = 592 (DelRey Hardcover ed.) | isbn = 0-575-07342-X |isbn_note= (first edition, paperback) &
{{ISBN|0-575-07341-1}} (hardback edition) | oclc= 50527130 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Evolution''''' is a collection of short stories that work together to form an episodic [[science fiction]] novel by author [[Stephen Baxter (author)|Stephen Baxter]]. It follows 565 million years of human evolution, from [[shrewlike]] mammals 65 million years in the past to the ultimate fate of humanity (and its descendants, both biological and non-biological) 500 million years in the future. ==Plot summary== The book follows the evolution of mankind as it shapes surviving [[Purgatorius]] into tree dwellers, remoulds a group that drifts from Africa to a (then much closer) [[New World]] on a raft formed out of debris, and confronting others with a terrible dead end as ice clamps down on [[Antarctica]]. The stream of DNA runs on elsewhere, where ape-like creatures in North Africa are forced out of their diminishing forests to come across grasslands where their distant descendants will later run joyously. At one point, hominids become [[Sapience|sapient]], and go on to develop technology, including an evolving [[universal assembler|universal constructor]] machine that goes to Mars and multiplies, and in an act of [[global ecophagy]] consumes Mars by converting the planet into a mass of machinery that leaves the Solar system in search of new planets to assimilate. [[Human extinction]] (or the extinction of human culture) also occurs in the book, as well as the end of planet Earth and the rebirth of life on another planet. (The [[extinction-level event]] that causes the human extinction is, indirectly, an eruption of the [[Rabaul caldera]], coupled with various actions of humans themselves, some of which are only vaguely referred to, but implied to be a form of genetic engineering which removed the ability to reproduce with non-engineered humans.) Also to be found in ''Evolution'' are ponderous Romans, sapient [[dinosaur]]s, the last of the wild [[Neanderthal]]s, a primate who witnesses the extinction of the dinosaurs, [[symbiotic]] primate-tree relationships, mole people, and primates who live on a Mars-like Earth. The final chapter witnesses the final fate of the last primate and the descendants of the replicator machines sent to [[Mars]] that are implied to have reached sentience and colonized the galaxy. In the epilogue, Joan Useb (a paleontologist introduced in the prologue and in the intermission sections) discusses the philosophy of evolution with her daughter Lucy as they weather the aftermath of Rabaul on the [[Galapagos]], where [[Charles Darwin]] made his observations leading to his landmark theory. ==Reception== [[Peter Cannon]] reviewing for ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' stated "here is a rigorously constructed hard SF novel where the question is not whether humanity will reach the stars but how it will survive its own worst tendencies."{{cite journal|last=Cannon|first=Peter|date=January 20, 2003|title=EVOLUTION (Book)|journal=Publishers Weekly|volume= 250|issue= 3|pages=61|issn=0000-0019}} ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' called this novel "glum, dyspeptic, and depressing."{{cite journal|date=November 15, 2002|title=EVOLUTION (Book)|journal=Kirkus Reviews|volume= 70|issue= 22,|pages=1662|issn=0042-6598}} Jackie Cassada said in her review for ''[[Library Journal]]'' that "spanning more than 165 million years and encompassing the entire planet, Baxter's ambitious saga provides both an exercise in painless paleontology and superb storytelling."{{cite journal|last=Cassada|first=Jackie |date=February 15, 2003|title=Evolution (Book)|journal=Library Journal|volume= 128|issue= 3|pages=172}} ''Evolution'' has been compared to [[Olaf Stapledon]]'s ''[[Last and First Men]]'' and Baxter has acknowledged Stapledon's influence.{{cite web|url=http://www.hd-image.com/interviews/myles_cabot_07.htm|title=An Interview with Stephen Baxter|work=Aberrant Dreams|accessdate=31 July 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Isfdb title|id=23350}} * Lengthy review at http://www.indymedia.ie/article/74240 {{Stephen __NOTOC__ [[File:Alpine flora.png|thumb|right|220px|Flora typical of the [[Alpine Region of the Alps]]]] The [[Alps]] are one of the great mountain range systems of Europe stretching approximately 1,200 kilometres (750 mi) across eight Alpine countries from Austria and Slovenia in the east, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Germany, France to the west and Italy and Monaco to the south. The '''flora of the Alps''' are diverse. In the [[mountain]]s, the [[vegetation]] gradually changes with [[altitude]], sun exposure, and location on the mountain. There are five successive [[life zone]]s, each with distinct [[landscape]]s and vegetation characteristics: [[premontane]], [[montane]], [[subalpine]], [[alpine climate|alpine]], and [[alvar]].{{cn|date=March 2016}}
==List of Alpine plants== {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

revision.text:
{{Proofreader needed|GNC仮説|ja}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2015}}
The '''GNC hypothesis''' or '''GNC-SNS primeval genetic code hypothesis''' refers to a hypothesis about the origin of genes. It suggests the universal genetic code originated not from a three-amino acid system, but from a four-amino acid system. It is this GNC code encoding [GADV]-proteins which is the most primitive genetic code. This hypothesis was first proposed by [[Kenji Ikehara]] at Nara Women's University.
==Details== While almost all of the [[organism]]s on Earth share the universal [[genetic code]], in the GNC hypothesis it is argued that two primeval genetic codes preceded the present genetic code as follows:
* First, there emerged [[Guanine|G]]N[[Cytosine|C]] primeval genetic codes involving 4 [[Genetic code|codons]] (GGC, GCC, G[[Adenine|A]]C and G[[Uracil|U]]C), which code 4 GADV-[[amino acid]]s ([[glycine]], [[alanine]], [[aspartic acid]] and [[valine]]). * Second, GNC code evolved to SNS primeval genetic codes involving 16 codons (GGC, GGG, GCC, GCG, GAC, GAG, GUC, GUG, CUC, GUG, CCC, CCG, CAC, CAG, CGC and CGG), which code 10 amino acids (glycine, alanine, aspartic acid, valine, [[glutamic acid]], [[leucine]], [[proline]], [[histidine]], [[glutamine]], [[arginine]]).
The GNC hypothesis is based on the following facts:
* [[Protein]]s composed of GADV-amino acids coded by GNC primeval genetic code can form four fundamental structures found in proteins in present organisms, namely, [[Hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] and [[Hydrophile|hydrophilic]] structures, [[Alpha helix|α-helices]], [[Beta sheet|β-sheets]], and [[turn (biochemistry)|turn]]s (or coils). * Proteins composed of ten amino acids coded by SNS primeval genetic code can form six fundamental structures, namely, hydrophobic and hydrophilic structures, α-helices, β-sheets, turns, [[acidic]] and [[Base (chemistry)|basic]] fragments.
== Related literatures == {{Cite journal|first1 = Kenji|last1 = Ikehara|first2 = Yoko|last2 = Omori|first3 = Rieko|last3 = Arai|first4 = Akiko|last4 = Hirose|title = A Novel Theory on the Origin of the Genetic Code: A GNC-SNS Hypothesis|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00239-001-0053-6|year = 2002|journal = Journal of Molecular Evolution|publisher = [[Springer-Verlag]]|volume = 54|issue = |pages = 530–538|doi = 10.1007/s00239-001-0053-6|pmid=11956691|bibcode = 2002JMolE..54..530I}}
== See also == * [[GADV protein world]]
[[Category:Evolution]] [[Category:Genetics]]

revision.text:
[[File:LakeChamoCrocodile.jpg|thumb|[[Lake Chamo]], a [[Rift Valley lakes|Rift Valley lake]] in the main Ethiopian rift]]
The '''Great Rift Valley''' of [[Ethiopia]], (or Main Ethiopian Rift or Ethiopian Rift Valley) is a branch of the [[East African Rift]] that runs through [[Ethiopia]] in a southwest direction from the [[Afar Triple Junction]]. In the past, it was seen as part of a "[[Great Rift Valley, geographical concept|Great Rift Valley]]" that ran from [[Mozambique]] to [[Syria]].
==Description==
The Great Rift Valley lies between the Ethiopian Plateau to the north and the Somalia Plateau to the south.<ref>{{cite web |ref={{harvid|CNR}} |url=http://ethiopianrift.igg.cnr.it/rift%20valley%20geography.htm |title=The Ethiopian rift valley: geography and morphology |publisher=CNR-IGG |author=G. Corti |accessdate=2013-08-02}}</ref> The [[rift]] developed as the [[Nubian Plate|Nubian]] and [[Somali plate|Somali]] plates began to separate during the [[Miocene]] Period along the East African rift system. Rift initiation was asynchronous along the Ethiopian rift valley: deformation began around 18 million years ago at the south end, around 11 million years ago close to the Afar depression and probably around 6-8 million years ago in the central sector.<ref>Bonini M., Corti G., Innocenti F., Manetti P., Mazzarini F., Abebe T., Pecskay Z; ''The evolution of the Main Ethiopian Rift in the frame of Afar and Kenya rifts propagation,'' Tectonics, 24, TC1007, doi:10.1029/2004TC001680</ref> The rift is extending in an ESE-WNW direction at about {{convert|5|-|7|mm|in|abbr=off}} annually.<ref>Corti, G.; ''Continental rift evolution: from rift initiation to incipient breakup in the Main Ethiopian Rift, East Africa,'' Earth-Science Reviews, v. 96, p. 1–53</ref>
The Ethiopian rift valley is about {{convert|80|km|mi}} wide and bordered on both margins by large, discontinuous [[normal fault]]s that give rise to major tectonic escarpments separating the rift floor from the surrounding plateaus. These faults are now thought to be inactive at the northern rift valley termination, whereas to the south they are still tectonically and seismically active.<ref>Keir, D., Ebinger, C.J., Stuart, G.W., Daly, E. and Ayele, A. ''Strain accommodation by magmatism and faulting as rifting proceeds to breakup: seismicity of the northern Ethiopian rift,'' Journal of Geophysical Research, 111(B5), B05314, doi: 10.1029/2005JB003748</ref><ref>Agostini A., Bonini M., Corti G., Sani F., Manetti P.; ''Distribution of Quaternary deformation in the central Main Ethiopian Rift, East Africa,'' Tectonics, 30, TC4010, doi:10.1029/2010TC002833</ref> The rift floor is cut by a series of smaller en echelon, right-stepping, rift basins of [[Quaternary]] to recent age. These basins are about {{convert|20|km|mi}} wide and {{convert|60|km|mi}} long. In the northern part of the rift, extension within the valley is now thought to be mainly along these faulted and [[magma]]tically active segments. These segments are considered to be developing [[mid ocean ridge]] spreading centers.<ref>{{cite web|ref={{harvid|School of Earth and Environment}} |url=http://www.see.leeds.ac.uk/afar/websitepages/structurepages/mer.htm |title=Geology of the Main Ethiopian Rift |publisher=University of Leeds |author=School of Earth and Environment |accessdate=2011-12-19}}</ref><ref>Ebinger, C. J. and M. Casey; ''Continental breakup in magmatic provinces: An Ethiopian example,'' Geology, v. 29 no. 6 p. 527-530</ref><ref>Corti, G.; ''Continental rift evolution: from rift initiation to incipient break-up in the Main Ethiopian Rift, East Africa,'' Earth-Science Reviews, v. 96, p. 1–53</ref>
== Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes == [[File:Ethiopia central lakes.jpg|right|thumb]]
The Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes are the northernmost of the African Rift Valley Lakes. The Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes occupy the floor of the rift valley between the two highlands. Most of the Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes do not have an outlet, and most are [[Alkalinity|alkaline]]. Although the Ethiopian Rift Valley Lakes are of great importance to Ethiopia's economy, as well as being essential to the survival of the local people, there were no intensive and extensive [[limnological]] studies undertaken of these lakes until recently.<ref>{{cite web |ref=harv |url=http://www.euronet.nl/users/backhuys/tuet.htm |title=Ethiopian Rift Valley Lakes|publisher=www.euronet.nl |accessdate=2008-03-16 |year=2002 |last=Hynes |first=H.B.N.}}</ref>
The major ones are * [[Lake Abaya]] (1162 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1285 m), the largest Ethiopian Rift Valley lake * [[Lake Chamo]] (551 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1235 m) * [[Lake Zway]] (485 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1636 m) * [[Lake Shala]] (329 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1558 m), the deepest Ethiopian Rift Valley lake * [[Lake Koka]] (250 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1590 m) * [[Lake Langano]] (230 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1585 m) * [[Lake Abijatta]] (205 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1573 m) * [[Lake Awasa]] (129 km<sup>2</sup>, elevation 1708 m)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{coord missing|Ethiopia}}
[[Category:Plate tectonics]] [[Category:Great Rift Valley]] [[Category:Geology of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Volcanoes of Ethiopia]]

'''Indian River''' is the name of two rivers in the U.S. state of Michigan:
* [[Indian River (Manistique River)]], in Alger and Schoolcraft counties in the Upper Peninsula * [[Indian River (Mullett Lake)]], in Cheboygan County in the Lower Peninsula
== See also == * [[Indian River, Michigan]], an unincorporated community in Cheboygan County * [[Little Indian River (Michigan)]], a tributary of Indian River in the Upper Peninsula

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = João Mangabeira |birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1880|06|26}} |birth_place = [[Salvador, Bahia]], [[Brazil]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1964|04|27|1880|06|26}} |death_place = [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)]], [[Brazil]] |occupation = {{flat list| * jurist * writer * politician }} |parents = Francisco Cavalcanti Mangabeira
Augusta Cavalcanti Mangabeira }} '''João Mangabeira''' (26 June 1880 – 27 April 1964) was a [[Brazil]]ian jurist, politician and writer. ==Biography== Brother of the medical doctor and poet [[Francisco Mangabeira]], and also of the politician [[Otávio Mangabeira]]. He was admitted to law school at 13 years old. Despite belonging to a large family without large financial resources, he managed to complete his course at the age of 17. Then goes to advocate in [[Ilhéus]], [[Bahia]]. According to [[Paulo Brossard]], "when the annual session of the jury starts, went on trial a poor defendant without a lawyer. As defense lawyer the Judge designated João Mangabeira. He knew nothing about the process. Listening to the Judge's report, paid attention to everything: names, pages, details. As soon as the Prosecutor concluded the indictment, the young defense lawyer, appointed minutes before, shatters the charge, pointing out contradictions, correcting names, indicating process pages that he do not handle at all. The defendant was acquitted ... and, thereafter, the city begun to trust the lawyer who was no more than a child, and his office start to have clients." Shortly after he became a congressman as State Deputy and then as Federal Deputy. Some circumstances made him close to [[Rui Barbosa]], who would always follow. In 1923, when Rui died, he gave the speech in honor of the master. On the centenary of birth of Rui Barbosa (1949), João was the speaker of the House of Representatives. In a short time he became one of the most prominent figures in the House of Representatives. Renowned as congressman and as a lawyer, he came to be among the highest expressions of the country's intelligence. His political activity was marked defending the [[socialism]]. Deputy for the [[Constitutional Assembly]] of 1934, and the combat against the Estado Novo dictatorship ([[Vargas Era]]) put him 15 months in prison. "I'd rather get in jail by this dictatorship, than be free, agreeing with it," he said in 1936. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mangabeira, Joao}} [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1964 deaths]] [[Category:Brazilian lawyers]] [[Category:Brazilian male writers]] [[Category:People from Bahia]] [[Category:Government ministers of Brazil]] [[Category:Justice ministers|Brazil]] [[Category:Energy ministers|Brazil]] [[Category:Energy in Brazil|Minister]] [[Category:Members of the Chamber of Deputies (Brazil) from Bahia]] [[Category:Members of the Federal Senate]] [[Category:Members of the Legislative Assembly of Bahia]] {{Brazil-politician-stub}}

= | programme = | previous_mission = [[Kitsat-1]] | next_mission = [[Kitsat-3]] | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''Kitsat-2''' ([[Pseudonym|a.k.a.]] ''"Uribyol 2", "Kitsat-OSCAR 25", "KO 25" and "KitSAT B"'') was a [[South Korea]]n experimental [[Earth observation satellite|earth observation]] [[Miniaturized satellite#Microsatellites|microsatellite]]. Kitsat-2 was South Korea's second satellite and was the first to be developed and manufactured domestically by the [[KAIST|Korea Advanced Institute of Science]]. The satellite was launched into [[orbit]] on 26 September 1993, on the 59th flight of the [[Ariane 4|Ariane-40 H10]] [[expendable launch vehicle]]. The launch took place in the [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou Space Centre]], [[French Guiana]]. The satellite's mission was to improve and enhance the [[Kitsat-1]] systems, use domestically manufactured components, demonstrate experimental modules and to promote domestic space industry.{{cite news|title=KITSAT series - KITSAT-2|publisher=[[KAIST Satellite Technology Research Center]]|accessdate=9 Jul 2016|url=http://satrec.kaist.ac.kr/e_02_01_01.php}}{{cite news|title=KITSAT-OSCAR 25|publisher=om3ktr.sk|accessdate=9 Jul 2016|url=http://www.om3ktr.sk/druzice/ko25.html}}{{cite news|title=KITSAT 2|publisher=n2yo.com|accessdate=9 Jul 2016|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=22828}}{{cite news|title=KITSAT 2 COSPAR ID: 1993-061F|publisher=[[NASA]]|accessdate=9 Jul 2016|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1993-061F}}{{cite news|title=Kitsat 1, 2 (Uribyol 1, 2 / Kitsat-OSCAR 23, 25 / KO 23, 25)|publisher=Gunter's space page|accessdate=9 Jul 2016|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/kitsat-1.htm}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[Kitsat-1]] * [[Kitsat-3]] * [[PSLV-C2]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Portal bar|Korea|Space|Science}} {{South Korean Space Program}} {{Orbital launches in 1993}} [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] [[Category:First artificial satellite of a country]] [[Category:Satellites of South Korea]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1993]] [[Category:Amateur radio satellites]] {{spacecraft-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}} '''Lake breakout''' is a [[geological]] term that refers to the collapse of a (usually high-altitude) lake. High-altitude lakes tend to form in [[volcanic crater]]s – where they are called [[crater lake]]s – or in valleys dammed as the result of [[earthquake]]s or [[glacier|glacial]] or volcanic deposition. Lake breakouts are most common a few weeks or months after a [[volcanic eruption]] as a river becomes blocked by volcanic debris. ==Process== The walls of such lakes can be unstable and may be breached after fresh earthquakes or because of [[erosion]]. As water rushes outwards, the initial channel is cut wider and deeper, further increasing the flow. This may cause the lake's rim to collapse abruptly. The usual result is for huge amounts of water to be displaced, incorporating a great deal of [[sediment]] which increases it in volume by as much as two or four times, or even more. This produces violent floods and [[lahar]]s with devastating effects for any settlements in their path. ==Historical events== The larger a temporary lake is, the more extreme the likely breakout will be. One of the largest known to have occurred in recent geological history was the collapse, around 15,000 years ago, of the ancient [[Lake Bonneville]] which was filled with meltwater from the last [[ice age]] and covered large areas of [[Utah]], [[Idaho]] and [[Nevada]]. Erosion broke through the lake shore's lowest point, the [[Red Rock Pass]] in Idaho, releasing as much as 1,000 mile³ (4,000 km³) of water within a period estimated to have lasted only two weeks. The energies released by the outburst were capable not just of stripping surface features, but gouging out bedrock to a depth of many feet. It drastically reshaped the landscape downstream, carving out many of the features of the [[Snake River]] and its surrounding area. [[Glacial Lake Missoula]] also had lake breakouts, due to breaking of ice dams, see [[Missoula Floods]]. These lake breakouts caused extensive erosion throughout eastern [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. It has been suggested that gigantic breakouts from underground lakes may have been responsible for carving some of the [[canyon]]s of [[Mars]].
==Mitigation== Although there is little that can be done about many lake breakouts, some have been prevented (or at least delayed) by human intervention. The [[1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens]] blocked nearby Castle Creek, forming a lake which geologists feared would produce a sudden lahar. The [[United States]] [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Army Corps of Engineers]] excavated an outlet channel which prevented the lake from overtopping its new [[debris dam]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lake Breakout}} [[Category:Flood]] [[Category:Volcanoes]] [[Category:Seismology]]

[[1647 Santiago earthquake|1647]]
}} }} This '''list of earthquakes in Chile''' includes every known major earthquake that was felt or with its epicenter within Chile's current boundaries. ==Statistics and Map== {|class="wikitable floatleft" style="text-align:center" !Century!! Number with
M ≥ 7.0 !! Average per
decade |- |1501–1600 || 3 || - |- |1601–1700 || 6 || - |- |1701–1800 || 4 || - |- |1801–1900 || 19 || - |- |1901–2000 || 76 || 7.6 |- |2001–present || 15 || 7.5 |- |'''Total'''|| '''123''' || '''-''' |} Statistics for earthquakes with M ≥ 7.0 in Chile are detailed on the list below. The region, which is adjacent to the fast-moving [[Nazca Plate]], has high tectonic activity. To keep the list manageable, only earthquakes with magnitude ≥ 7.0 will be included, or if it is has other notable features like the [[2010 Pichilemu earthquake]]. The records for earlier centuries are apparently incomplete. Of the [[Lists of earthquakes#Largest earthquakes by magnitude|world's known earthquakes with M ≥ 8.5]] since the year 1500, one-third occurred in Chile and are shown in the map to the side. Some virtually have the same epicenters like the 1604 and [[1868 Arica earthquake|1868]] (in Arica), the [[1730 Valparaíso earthquake|1730]] and 1822 (in Valparaíso), and the [[1751 Concepción earthquake|1751]] and [[1835 Concepción earthquake|1835]] (in Concepción). The strongest known recorded in modern times was also in Chile, the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake]]. ==Earthquakes== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Region !! Local

revision.text:
{{distinguish|List of largest stars}} This is a '''list of the most massive [[star]]s''' so far discovered, in [[solar mass]]es ({{Solar mass|link=y}}). ==Uncertainties and caveats== Most of the masses listed below are contested and, being the subject of current research, remain under review and subject to revision. Indeed, many of the masses listed in the table below are inferred from theory, using difficult measurements of the stars’ temperatures and absolute brightnesses. All the masses listed below are uncertain: both the theory and the measurements are pushing the limits of current knowledge and technology. Either measurement or theory, or both, could be incorrect. For example, [[VV Cephei]] could be between {{Solar mass|25–40|link=y}}, or {{Solar mass|100}}, depending on which property of the star is examined. [[File:Dust disk around massive star.jpg|thumb|200px|Artist's impression of disc of obscuring material around a massive star.]] Massive stars are rare; [[astronomer]]s must look very far from the [[Earth]] to find one. All the listed stars are many thousands of light years away and that alone makes measurements difficult. In addition to being far away, many stars of such extreme mass are surrounded by clouds of outflowing gas created by powerful [[stellar wind]]s; the surrounding gas interferes with the already difficult-to-obtain measurements of stellar temperatures and brightnesses and greatly complicates the issue of estimating internal chemical compositions.For some methods, different determinations of chemical composition lead to different estimates of mass. Both the obscuring clouds and the great distances make it difficult to judge whether the star is just a single supermassive object or, instead, a [[multiple star]] system. A number of the "stars" listed below may actually be two or more companions orbiting too closely to distinguish, each star being massive in itself but not necessarily “supermassive”. Other combinations are possible – for example a supermassive star with one or more smaller companions or more than one giant star – but without being able to see inside the surrounding cloud, it is difficult to know the truth of the matter. More globally, statistics on stellar populations seem to indicate that the upper mass limit is in the 100–200 solar mass range.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} ===Rare reliable estimates=== Eclipsing binary stars are the only stars whose masses are estimated with some confidence. However note that almost all of the masses listed in the table below were inferred by indirect methods; only a few of the masses in the table were determined using eclipsing systems. Amongst the most reliable listed masses are those for the eclipsing binaries [[NGC 3603-A1]], [[WR21a]], and [[Westerlund 2|WR20a]]. Masses for all three were obtained from orbital measurements.For a binary star, it is possible to measure the individual masses of the two stars by studying their orbital motions, using [[Kepler's laws of planetary motion]]. This involves measuring their [[Radial velocity|radial velocities]] and also their light curves. The radial velocities only yield minimum values for the masses, depending on inclination, but light curves of eclipsing binaries provide the missing information: inclination of the orbit to our line of sight. ===Relevance of stellar evolution=== Some stars may once have been heavier than they are today. It is likely that many have suffered significant mass loss, perhaps as much as several tens of solar masses, expelled by the process of [[superwind]], where high velocity winds are expelled from the hot [[photosphere]] into interstellar space. This process is similar to superwinds generated by [[Asymptotic Giant Branch]] (AGB) stars in form [[red giant]]s or [[planetary nebula]]e. The process forms an enlarged extended envelope around the star that interacts with the nearby interstellar medium and infusing the region with elements heavier than Hydrogen or Helium. There are also – or rather ''were'' – stars that might have appeared on the list but no longer exist as stars, or are [[supernova impostor]]s; today we see only the debris.For examples of stellar debris see [[hypernovae]] and [[supernova remnant]]. The masses of the precursor stars that fueled these cataclysms can be estimated from the type of explosion and the energy released, but those masses are not listed here (see the section [[#Black holes]] below). ===Mass limits=== There are two related theoretical limits on how massive a star can possibly be. One is related to star formation: After about 120 {{Solar mass|link=y}} have accreted in a [[protostar]], the combined mass should have become hot enough for its heat to drive away any further incoming matter. In effect, the protostar reaches a point where it evaporates material away as fast as it collects new material. The other limit is based on light pressure from the core of an already-formed star: As mass increases past ~150 {{Solar mass}}, the intensity of light radiated from a [[Population I]] star's core will become sufficient for the light-pressure pushing outward to exceed the gravitational force pulling inward, and the surface material of the star will be free to float away into space. ;Eddington mass limit {{Main|Eddington luminosity}} A limit on stellar mass arises because of light-pressure: For a sufficiently massive star the outward [[pressure]] of radiant [[energy]] generated by [[nuclear fusion]] in the star’s core exceeds the inward pull of its own [[gravity]]. This effect is called the [[Eddington limit]]. Stars of greater mass have a higher rate of core energy generation, and heavier stars' luminosities increase far out of proportion to the increase in their masses. The [[Eddington limit]] is the point, beyond which a star ought to push itself apart, or at least shed enough mass to reduce its internal energy generation to a lower, maintainable rate. The actual limit-point mass depends on how opaque the gas in the star is, and metal-rich [[Population I]] stars have lower mass limits than metal-poor [[Population II]] stars, with the hypothetical metal-free [[Population III]] stars having the highest allowed mass, somewhere around 300 {{Solar mass}}. In theory, a more massive star could not hold itself together because of the mass loss resulting from the outflow of stellar material. In practice the theoretical Eddington Limit must be modified for high luminosity stars and the empirical [[Humphreys-Davidson limit]] is used instead.{{cite journal |last1=Ulmer |first1=A. |last2=Fitzpatrick |first2=E. L. |doi=10.1086/306048 |title=Revisiting the modified Eddington limit for massive stars |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=504 |pages=200–206 |year=1998 |arxiv=astro-ph/9708264 |bibcode=1998ApJ...504..200U}} ;Accretion limits Astronomers have long hypothesized that as a [[protostar]] grows to a size beyond 120 {{Solar mass|link=y}}, something drastic must happen. Although the limit can be stretched for very early [[Population III]] stars, and although the exact value is uncertain, if any stars still exist above 150–200 {{Solar mass}} they would challenge current theories of [[stellar evolution]]. Studying the [[Arches cluster]], which is currently the densest known cluster of stars in [[Milky Way Galaxy|our galaxy]], astronomers have confirmed that stars in that cluster do not occur any larger than about 150 {{Solar mass}}. Rare ultramassive stars that exceed this limit – for example in the [[R136]] star cluster – might be explained by the following proposal: Some of the pairs of massive [[binary star|stars in close orbit]] in young, unstable [[Star system#Trapezia|multiple-star systems]] must occasionally collide and merge where certain unusual circumstances hold that make a collision possible.{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.21672.x |title=The emergence of super-canonical stars in R136-type starburst clusters |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=426 |issue=2 |pages=1416–1426 |year=2012 |last1=Banerjee |first1=S. |last2=Kroupa |first2=P. |last3=Oh |first3=S. |bibcode=2012MNRAS.426.1416B |arxiv=1208.0826}} ==List of the most massive stars== The following is a list of a few stars with an estimated mass of 25 {{Solar mass|link=y}} or greater, including the stars of [[Arches cluster|Arches]] cluster, [[Cygnus OB2]] cluster, [[Pismis 24]] cluster, and [[R136]] cluster. Note that ''all'' [[O-type star]]s have masses greater than 15 {{Solar mass}} and catalogs of such stars (GOSS, Reed) list hundreds of cases. The majority of stars thought to be more than 100 {{Solar mass}} are shown, but this list is far from complete – especially below 80 {{Solar mass}}. The method used to determine the mass is included in the list to give an idea of uncertainty: direct methods (binary stars) being more secure than indirect ones (conversion from luminosity, extrapolation from stellar atmosphere models, ...). The masses listed below are the stars’ ''current'' (evolved) mass, not their initial (formation) mass. {{Expand list|date=January 2016}} {| class="wikitable floatright" style="width: 209px;" |+'''Legend''' |- | style="background: {{star-color|WC}};"| [[Wolf–Rayet star]] |- | style="background: {{star-color|WN}};"| [[Luminous blue variable]] star |- | style="background: {{star-color|O}};" | [[O-type main-sequence star|O-class star]] |- | style="background: {{star-color|B}};" | [[B-type main-sequence star|B-class star]] |- | style="background: {{star-color|M}};" | [[Hypergiant]] |- |} [[File:EtaCarinae.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Eta Carinae]], the most massive star that has a [[Bayer designation]]]] [[File:Grand star-forming region R136 in NGC 2070 (captured by the Hubble Space Telescope).jpg|thumb|200px|right|The [[R136]] cluster]] [[File:Image of the WR 25 binary.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[WR 25]]]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! width="160"| Star name ! Leutenegger|doi=10.1093/mnras/stv2783|bibcode = 2016MNRAS.456.2907P|volume=456|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|issue=3|pages=2907–2936|year=2015}} | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|B}};"|[[19 Cephei]] |30–35 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|WC}};" |[[γ Velorum]] A ''(Regor A)'' |30 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|WN}};"|[[P Cygni]] |30 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|M}};"|[[VY Canis Majoris]] |30 (17–40) | |{{cite web|title=VLT image of the surroundings of VY Canis Majoris seen with SPHERE|url=https://www.eso.org/public/images/eso1546a/|website=www.eso.org|accessdate=15 June 2018}}{{cite journal | doi = 10.1051/0004-6361/201219126 | last1 = Wittkowski | first1 = M. | last2 = Hauschildt | first2 = P.H. | last3 = Arroyo-Torres | first3 = B. | last4 = Marcaide | first4 = J.M. | title = Fundamental properties and atmospheric structure of the red supergiant VY CMa based on VLTI/AMBER spectro-interferometry | journal = Astronomy & Astrophysics | volume = 540 | pages = L12 | date = 5 April 2012 | bibcode=2012A&A...540L..12W|arxiv=1203.5194}} |- | style="background: {{star-color|O}};"|[[VFTS 352]] |A=28.63 ± 0.3, B=28.85 ± 0.3 | |{{cite journal |title=DISCOVERY OF THE MASSIVE OVERCONTACT BINARY VFTS 352: EVIDENCE FOR ENHANCED INTERNAL MIXING |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |date=13 October 2015 |last=Almeida |first=L. A. |last2=Sana |first2=H. |last3=de Mink |first3=S. E. |volume=812 |issue=2 |pages=102 |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0004-637X/812/2/102 |accessdate=2015-10-21 |display-authors=etal|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/812/2/102 |bibcode=2015ApJ...812..102A |arxiv = 1509.08940 }} |- | style="background: {{star-color|WN}};" |[[The Pistol Star]] ([[The Pistol Star|V4647 Sgr]]) |27.5 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|O}};" |[[10 Lacertae]] |26.9 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|O}};"|[[Xi Persei|ξ Persei]] (''Menkib'') |26–36 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|B}};"|[[6 Cassiopeiae]] |25 | |{{cite journal|bibcode=1997A&A...320..196A|title=Radiation driven wind models for A, F and G supergiants|journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics|volume=320|pages=196|author1=Achmad|first1=L.|last2=Lamers|first2=H. J. G. L. M.|last3=Pasquini|first3=L.|year=1997}} |- | style="background: {{star-color|O}};"|[[Pismis 24|Pismis 24-3]] |25 | | |- | style="background: {{star-color|B}};"|[[NGC 7538]] S |25 | |{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1051/0004-6361/201423420| title = A multiple system of high-mass YSOs surrounded by disks in NGC 7538 IRS1| journal = Astronomy & Astrophysics| volume = 566| pages = A150| year = 2014| last1 = Moscadelli | first1 = L.| last2 = Goddi | first2 = C. | bibcode=2014A&A...566A.150M|arxiv = 1404.3957 }} |- | style="background: {{star-color|O}};"|[[VFTS 102]] |25 | | |} ==Black holes== {{Main|Black hole|List of black holes|List of most massive black holes}} [[Black hole]]s are the end point evolution of massive stars. Technically they are not stars, as they no longer generate heat and light via nuclear fusion in their cores.Note that some [[black hole]]s may have cosmological origins, and would then never have been stars. This is thought to be especially likely in the cases of the [[Supermassive black hole|most massive black holes]]. * [[Stellar black hole]]s are objects with approximately 4–15 {{Solar mass|link=y}}. * [[Intermediate-mass black hole]]s range from 100–10 000 {{Solar mass}}. * [[Supermassive black hole]]s are in the range of millions or billions {{Solar mass}}. ==See also== {{Portal|Star}} {{cmn|colwidth=18em| * [[Hypergiant]] * [[Luminous blue variable]] * [[Supergiant]] * [[List of least massive stars]] * [[List of hottest stars]] * [[List of largest stars]] * [[List of most luminous stars]] * [[List of brightest stars]] * [[Lists of stars]] * [[List of most massive black holes]] * [[List of largest nebulae]] * [[List of largest galaxies]] * [[List of largest cosmic structures]] * [[Wolf–Rayet star]] }} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/2005/05/ Statistics in Arches cluster] * [http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/070607_massive_star.html Most Massive Star Discovered] * [https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2005/03/050309142833.htm Arches cluster] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071028091902/http://www.3towers.com/sGrasslands/Essays/HeavyStar/HeavyStar01.asp How Heavy Can a Star Get?] * [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2004ApJ...610L.109F&db_key=AST&data_type=HTML& LBV 1806-20] {{Star}} {{Supernovae}} {{Black holes}} [[Category:Lists of stars]] [[Category:Lists of superlatives in astronomy|Stars, most massive]] [[Category:Lists of astronomical objects]]

{{See also|List of nature centers in the United States}} <!-- Note: Please do not add websites for nature centers with existing Wikipedia articles. All websites should be listed on the main article. -->
This is a list of [[nature center]]s and environmental education centers in the state of [[South Carolina]].
To use the sortable tables: click on the icons at the top of each column to sort that column in alphabetical order; click again for reverse alphabetical order.
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name ! Location ! County ! Region ! Summary |- | Blue Heron Nature Center || [[Ridgeland, South Carolina|Ridgeland]] || [[Jasper County, South Carolina|Jasper]] || [[South Carolina Lowcountry|Lowcountry]] || [https://www.facebook.com/Blue-Heron-Nature-Center-515138168609692/ Facebook site], 10 acres |- | [[Cape Romain National Wildlife Refuge]] || [[Awendaw, South Carolina|Awendaw]] || [[Charleston County, South Carolina|Charleston]] || [[Charleston–North Charleston–Summerville metropolitan area|Charleston Metro]] || 66,287 acres, Sewee Visitor and Environmental Education Center features displays about the various ecosystems, wildlife and heritage of the Lowcountry |- | Caw Caw Interpretive Center || [[Ravenel, South Carolina|Ravenel]] || Charleston || Charleston Metro || [http://sc-charlestoncountyparks.civicplus.com/index.asp?NID=53 website], operated by the County, over 6 miles of trails, former rice plantation wetlands |- | [[Coastal Discovery Museum]] || [[Hilton Head Island, South Carolina|Hilton Head Island]] || [[Beaufort County, South Carolina|Beaufort]] || Lowcountry || [http://www.coastaldiscovery.org/ website], 68 acres, art exhibits, guided nature and history walks and talks |- | [[Edisto Beach State Park]] || [[Edisto Beach, South Carolina|Edisto Beach]] || [[Colleton County, South Carolina|Colleton]] || Lowcountry || 1,255 acres, features the ACE Basin Interpretative Center |- | [[Francis Beidler Forest]] || [[Harleyville, South Carolina|Harleyville]] || [[Dorchester County, South Carolina|Dorchester]] || Charleston Metro || [[National Audubon Society]] wildlife sanctuary in [[Four Holes Swamp]] with an environmental education center, over 16,000 acres |- | [[Harbison State Forest]] || || [[Richland County, South Carolina|Richland]] ||[[Midlands (South Carolina)|Midlands]] || 2,177 acres, features the Harbison Environmental Education Center, programs, education trails |- | Heron Park Nature Center || [[Kiawah Island, South Carolina|Kiawah Island]] || Charleston || Charleston Metro || [http://www.kiawahresort.com/recreation/by-interest/nature-program website], part of [[Kiawah Island Golf Resort]], located in 21-acre Night Heron Park |- | Hilton Pond Center for Piedmont Natural History || [[York, South Carolina|York]] || [[York County, South Carolina|York]] || [[Olde English District]] || [http://www.hiltonpond.org/ website], 11 acres, open by appointment for guided field trips only, bird banding and research center |- | [[Hobcaw Barony|Hobcaw Barony Discovery Center]] || [[Georgetown, South Carolina|Georgetown]] || [[Georgetown County, South Carolina|Georgetown]] || [[Pee Dee]] || 17,500 acres, access by guided tours, exhibits on pine and cypress ecosystem and the history of the 17,500 acre property |- | [[Hunting Island State Park]] || [[Beaufort, South Carolina|Beaufort]] || [[Beaufort County, South Carolina|Beaufort]] || Lowcountry || 5,000-acre barrier island, features nature center, lighthouse, 4 miles of beach |- | [[Huntington Beach State Park]] || [[Murrells Inlet, South Carolina|Murrells Inlet]] || [[Georgetown County, South Carolina|Georgetown]] || Pee Dee || 2,500 acres, includes nature centers, [[Atalaya Castle (USA)|Atalaya Castle]] historic house |- | [[Lake Conestee Nature Park]] || [[Greenville, South Carolina|Greenville]] || [[Greenville County, South Carolina|Greenville]] || [[Upstate South Carolina|Upcountry]] || About 400 acres, managed through a partnership between the Conestee Foundation and the Greenville County Recreation District |- | [[Lee State Natural Area|Lee State Park]] || [[Bishopville, South Carolina|Bishopville]] || [[Lee County, South Carolina|Lee]] || Pee Dee || 2,839 acres, Lee Environmental Education Center features a wetland ecology lab and exhibits about the habitats and wildlife of the park |- | Lynches River County Park || [[Coward, South Carolina|Coward]] || [[Florence County, South Carolina|Florence]] || Pee Dee || [http://www.lynchesriverpark.com website], 676 acres, operated by the County, features Environmental Discovery Center |- | [[Magnolia Plantation and Gardens (Charleston, South Carolina)|Magnolia Plantation and Gardens]] || Charleston || Charleston || Charleston Metro || 70 acres, includes historic plantation house and outbuildings museum, gardens, zoo, nature center and a maze |- | Mobley Nature Center || [[Okatie, South Carolina|Okatie]] || [[Beaufort County, South Carolina|Beaufort]] || Lowcountry || [http://www.springisland.com/nature-center.html website], part of the [[Spring Island]] 3,000-acre nature preserve and residential community, center includes a library, museum, zoo and a classroom |- | [[Myrtle Beach State Park|Myrtle Beach State Park Nature Center]] || [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina|Myrtle Beach]] || [[Horry County, South Carolina|Horry]] || Pee Dee || 312 acres |- | Ocean Lakes Nature Center || [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina|Myrtle Beach]] || [[Horry County, South Carolina|Horry]] || Pee Dee || [http://www.oceanlakes.com/amenities/nature_center.aspx website], part of the Ocean Lakes Family Campground, focus on shells, fossils, sea life, wildlife and ecology of coastal South Carolina |- | Silver Bluff Audubon Center and Sanctuary || [[Jackson, South Carolina|Jackson]] || [[Aiken County, South Carolina|Aiken]] ||[[Augusta metropolitan area|Augusta area]] || [http://sc.audubon.org/silver-bluff-audubon-center-and-sanctuary website], 3,154 acres, operated by the [[National Audubon Society]] |- | [[South Carolina Botanical Garden]] || [[Clemson, South Carolina|Clemson]] || [[Pickens County, South Carolina|Pickens]] || Upcountry || 295 acres, includes gardens, 70 acre arboretum, Hanson Nature Learning Center, Bob Campbell Geology Museum and art exhibits |- | [[Table Rock State Park (South Carolina)|Table Rock State Park]] || [[Pickens, South Carolina|Pickens]] || [[Pickens County, South Carolina|Pickens]] || Upcountry || 3,083 acres |- | Tiedemann Park Nature Center || Charleston || Charleston || Charleston Metro || [http://www.charlestonparksconservancy.org/our_parks/view_park/tiedemann_playground/ website], operated by the City, focus on Low Country habitats, environments and wildlife |- | [[Waccamaw National Wildlife Refuge]] || [[Georgetown, South Carolina|Georgetown]] || [[Georgetown County, South Carolina|Georgetown]] || Pee Dee || 22,931 acres in 3 counties, visitor center and environmental education center in Georgetown |- | Walterboro Wildlife Sanctuary || [[Walterboro, South Carolina|Walterboro]] || [[Colleton County, South Carolina|Colleton]] || Lowcountry || [http://www.walterborosc.org/walterboro-wildlife-sanctuary.aspx website], 842-acre estuary preserve, planned Discovery Center, operated by the City |- | Webb Wildlife Center || [[Garnett, South Carolina|Garnett]] || [[Hampton County, South Carolina|Hampton]] || Lowcountry || [https://web.archive.org/web/20101123190217/https://www.dnr.sc.gov/mlands/managedland?p_id=108 website], 5,866 acres, state-operated wildlife management area |- | Wild Turkey Center and Winchester Museum || [[Edgefield, South Carolina|Edgefield]] || [[Edgefield County, South Carolina|Edgefield]] ||[[Augusta metropolitan area|Augusta area]] || [http://www.nwtf.org/about/hunting-heritage-center/wild-turkey-center website], operated by the [[National Wild Turkey Federation]], museum dedicated to wild turkey restoration, management and hunting, and 100 acre outdoor education center |- |}

==External links== * [https://www.google.com/maps/ms?msid=216417627346176875400.0004e4014179b60a385da&msa=0&ll=33.696923,-80.875854&spn=4.162855,9.684448 Map of nature centers and environmental education centers in South Carolina]

revision.text:
[[File:Brent Spot monthly.svg |thumb|right|250px|[[Price of oil|Crude oil prices]] from 1987 to 2012]]
In 2005 the [[government of Sweden]] appointed a commission to draw up a comprehensive programme to reduce [[Sweden]]'s dependence on [[petroleum]], [[natural gas]] and other ‘[[fossil fuel|fossil raw materials]]’ by 2020. In June 2006 (less than three months before the [[Swedish general election, 2006|2006 general election]]) the commission issued its report, entitled '''''Making Sweden an Oil-Free Society''''' ({{lang-sv|På väg mot ett oljefritt Sverige}}). The report cited four reasons to reduce oil dependence:<ref name='swegov2031'>{{cite web |url=http://www.sweden.gov.se/sb/d/2031/a/67096 |title=Making Sweden an OIL-FREE Society |author=[[Prime Minister of Sweden|Prime Minister]]'s Office Commission on Oil Independence |accessdate=2007-02-13}} </ref> *The impact of [[Price of oil|oil prices]] on [[Economy of Sweden|Swedish economic]] growth and employment *The link between oil, peace and security throughout the world *The great potential to use Sweden's own clean [[renewable energy]] resources in place of [[oil]] *The threat of [[global warming|climate change]] resulting from the extensive burning of [[fossil fuel]]s
As of 2005, oil supplies provided about 32% of the country's energy supply, with [[nuclear power]] and [[hydroelectricity]] providing much of the remainder. Although the report did not propose to end the use of oil entirely, the 2020 date was suggested as a marker on a continuing process of the "oil phase-out in Sweden".
Following defeat of the incumbent government coalition in the [[Swedish general election, 2006|2006 general election]], the proposals were not included in the energy policy or in any law. “Sweden’s energy policy, in both the short and the long term, is to safeguard the supply of electricity and other forms of energy on terms that are competitive with the rest of the world. It is intended to create the right conditions for efficient use of energy and a cost efficient Swedish supply of energy, with minimum adverse effect on health, the environment or climate, and assisting the move towards an ecologically [[sustainable]] society.”<ref name='EnerSwed2008'>{{cite web |url=http://www.energimyndigheten.se/en/Facts-and-figures1/Publications/ |title=Energy in Sweden 2008 |author=Swedish Energy Agency, of the [[Ministry of Enterprise, Energy and Communications (Sweden)]] |accessdate=2010-03-25}} </ref>
==Commission on Oil Independence== [[Image:gråbetongiangekullen.jpg|thumb|200px|Housing in [[Angered]].]] To make recommendations on how dependency on oil should be broken, the government created a Commission on Oil Independence (''Kommissionen för att bryta oljeberoendet i Sverige till år 2020''), headed by the then Prime Minister [[Göran Persson]], which reported in June 2006.
In their report, the Commission proposed the following targets for 2020:
*consumption of oil in [[road transport]] to be reduced by 40-50 per cent; *consumption of oil in [[industry]] to be cut by 25-40 per cent; *[[Central heating|heating buildings]] with oil, a practice already cut by 70% since the [[1973 oil crisis]], should be phased out; *overall, energy should be used 20% more efficiently.
[[Image:Heleneholmsverket, Malmö.jpg|thumb|200px|Power plant in [[Malmö]], 2006.]] Replacing oil with [[renewable energy]] sources and [[energy conservation]] measures to cut total energy use was envisioned. This is also expected to result in cuts in [[carbon emissions]] and to strengthen the country's role in [[sustainable development]] technologies as well as increasing its international economic competitiveness.
===Energy sources=== Technical solutions under consideration include the further development of domestically grown [[biofuel]]s, [[solar cell]]s, [[fuel cell]]s, [[wind farms]], [[wave energy]], a major increase in [[district heating]] schemes and greater use of [[geothermal heat pump]]s. It is expected that research, development and commercialization of such technologies should be supported by government.
The Commission also recommended that the government should not sanction the creation of a national [[natural gas]] infrastructure, on the belief that this would inhibit the development of [[biofuel]]s and encourage the use of gas in place of oil.
===Energy use=== [[Image:GothenburgTram1.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Gothenburg tram|Gothenburg tram system]], 1999.]] To cut energy use, the commission anticipated that by 2020 at least 75% of all new housing would use [[low-energy house|low-energy building]] techniques similar to the German [[Passive house]] standard, and that it will also be necessary to modernize the existing housing stock, including replacing direct [[electric heating]] systems (with systems heated by district heating, [[biofuel]]s or heat pumps).
They also expect there to be a greater use of [[Telecommuting|teleworking]], [[Videoconferencing|video conferencing]] and [[webconferencing|web conferencing]], [[public transport]], [[ship transport|sea transport]], [[hybrid vehicle]]s, and smaller, lighter, [[biodiesel]] cars.
As part of reducing industrial consumption, it is proposed that carbon allowances issued in Sweden under the [[European Union Emission Trading Scheme]] should be cut to 75% of their initial levels by 2020.
The taxation system is also likely to be used to influence energy choices, together with education and public awareness initiatives.
==Progress== On their release, the Commission's proposals were supported by the national automotive industry association, BIL Sweden. It was, however, opposed by the timber industry, who fear that land producing profitable exports may become used for low-income domestic [[biofuel]] production.<ref name='worldchange0048'> {{cite web |url = http://www.worldchanging.com/archives/004832.html |title = Letter from Sweden: Fossil Fuel-Free by 2020, Maybe |first = Alan |last = Akinsson |publisher = Worldchanging.com |date = 2006-08-16 |accessdate = 2007-02-13 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061115133219/http://www.worldchanging.com/archives/004832.html |archivedate = 2006-11-15 |df = }} </ref> As of 2008, 43% of the Swedish primary energy supply comes from renewable sources, which is the largest share in any European Union country.<ref name='SwedenRenewableShare'> {{cite web |url=http://renewabletech.blogspot.com/2008/07/sweden-has-got-largest-share-of.html |title=Sweden Has the Largest Share of Renewable Energy in Europe |first=Patrik |last=Marckert |publisher=blogspot.com |work = RenewableTech |date=2008-07-25 |accessdate=2008-08-13}} </ref>
In September, 2015, the Swedish government announced its plan to drastically cut its reliance on fossil fuels by 2020. This plan also includes the goal of having the capital, Stockholm, 100% powered by renewable resources by 2050. Though the goal is to have the entire country run on renewable resources, there is no temporal goal yet.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Regeringen investerar för klimatet|url = http://www.regeringen.se/pressmeddelanden/2015/09/regeringen-investerar-for-klimatet/|website = Regeringskansliet|date = 2015-09-16|accessdate = 2015-12-07|language = sv|first = Regeringen och|last = Regeringskansliet}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Sweden Boosts Renewables to Become First Fossil-Fuel-Free Nation|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-16/sweden-boosts-renewables-to-become-first-fossil-fuel-free-nation|website = Bloomberg.com|accessdate = 2015-12-07|first = Anna Hirtenstein|last = ahirtens}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Budget Bill for 2016 – Investing in Sweden’s future|url = http://www.government.se/press-releases/2015/09/the-budget-bill-for-2016--investing-in-swedens-future/|website = Regeringskansliet|date = 2015-09-21|accessdate = 2015-12-07|language = sv-se|first = Regeringen och|last = Regeringskansliet}}</ref>
== Ban of fossil fuel-driven vehicles == {{Further|Electric vehicle}}
Though they are currently in the opposition Alliance, [[Centre Party (Sweden)|Swedish political party Centerpartiet]] has proposed to ban gasoline [[fossil fuel]]-driven vehicles by 2025-2030.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trollhattansaab.net/archives/2008/11/sweden-ban-gasoline-driven-vehicles-by-2025.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117135505/http://www.trollhattansaab.net/archives/2008/11/sweden-ban-gasoline-driven-vehicles-by-2025.html |archivedate=2012-01-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://car-hot.biz/sweden-wants-to-ban-gasoline/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090410033734/http://car-hot.biz/sweden-wants-to-ban-gasoline/ |archivedate=2009-04-10 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |authors=Maud Olofsson näringsminister, Andreas Carlgren miljöminister, Eskil Erlandsson jordbruksminister, Åsa Torstensson infrastukturminister |date= |title=DN Debatt. "Förbjud bensinbilar 2025 och oljeeldning i hus 2020" |trans-title= |url=http://www.dn.se/debatt/forbjud-bensinbilar-2025-och-oljeeldning-i-hus-2020/ |format= |language=Swedish language |newspaper=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |location= |access-date=August 24, 2016 |via= |subscription= |quote=redirect from old link dn.se/opinion/debatt/forbjud-bensinbilar-2025-och-oljeeldning-i-hus-2020-1.465678}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Renewable Energy}} *[[Climate change in Sweden]] *[[Coal phase out]] *[[Alternative propulsion]] *[[Renewable_energy_in_Iceland#Hydrogen|Hydrogen fuel replacement in Iceland]] *[[Renewable energy development]] *[[Renewable energy in the European Union]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.swedishenergyagency.se/ Swedish Energy Agency] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110929143008/http://www.svenskbiogas.se/sb/docs/english/Biogastrain_produktblad_2005.pdf Sweden's first biogas train] *[http://www.svebio.se/?p=726 Swedish Bioenergy Association] *[http://www.sweden.se/eng/Home/Society/Sustainability/Reading/The-road-to-Swedens-oil-free-future/ The road to Sweden's oil-free future] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061026200850/http://www.iiea.com/images/managed/events_attachments/Towards%20an%20Oil%20Free%20Economy%20in%20Ireland-1.pdf Towards an Oil Free Economy in Ireland: Lessons from the Swedish Commission for Oil Independence Report] *[http://www.swedish-oil.ru/ SWEDISH OIL LLC] {{DEFAULTSORT:Making Sweden An Oil-Free Society}} [[Category:Biofuel in Sweden]] [[Category:Climate change in Sweden]] [[Category:Economy of Sweden]] [[Category:Energy in Sweden]] [[Category:Environmental reports]] [[Category:Fossil fuels in Sweden]] [[Category:Petroleum politics]] [[Category:Politics of Sweden]] [[Category:Renewable energy policy]] [[Category:Sustainability in Sweden]] [[Category:Transport in Sweden]]

Park|Wolin]]|lat_deg=53|lat_min=55|lon_deg=14|lon_min=30|position=right|1=Poland|marksize=10|mark=Green_pog.svg}} }} __NOTOC__ There are 23 '''[[national park]]s in [[Poland]]'''. These were formerly run by the Polish Board of National Parks (''Krajowy Zarząd Parków Narodowych''), but in 2004 responsibility for them was transferred to the Ministry of the Environment. Most national parks are divided into strictly and partially protected zones. Additionally, they are usually surrounded by a protective buffer zone called ''otulina''. In Poland, as amended by the ''Nature Conservation Act'' 2004 Tekst ustawy z dnia 16 kwietnia 2004 r. ''o ochronie przyrody'' (Dz. U. z 2009 r. Nr 151, poz. 1220) ''"covers an area of outstanding value for the environmental, scientific, social, cultural and educational, with an area of not less than 1000 ha , which is the protection of the whole nature and qualities of landscape . The national park created to preserve biodiversity, resources, objects and elements of inanimate nature and landscape values, restoring proper state of natural resources and components and reconstruct distorted nature habitats, plants , habitats of animals and habitats of fungi."'' The area of national parks is divided into different areas using separate methods of conservation. There are strict protection zone, active and landscape. In areas bordering the park designated as [[buffer zone]] of the national park. The buffer zone can be formed protective zone of game animals and are non-inclusion of hunting . National parks is available to visit, but tourism can be here only in designated areas, trails, roads, paths. National Parks are funded from the central budget . Are managed by the directors, as an advisory body to the Council of the park. The April 30, 2004 parks were supervised by the National Board of National Parks . From 1 May 2004, the duties were taken over by the Ministry of the Environment - Department of Forestry, Nature Conservation and Landscape since January 19, 2007 Independent Department for [[Natura 2000]] areas and National Parks. After the establishment of GDOŚ and RDOŚ October 15, 2008, the task under the supervision of the Minister of the Environment of the National Parks Conservation Department completed the Ministry of Environment. The Polish national parks are carried out numerous research programs. Parks play an important role in education, ecological society. The national parks you can visit, and tourism, and they provide a well-developed infrastructure of tourism. Many of them have specially prepared trails and centers of educational and natural history museums. {{clear}} {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! class="unsortable" | ! class="unsortable" | Image !
